{{distinguish|Claudio Bravo (footballer, born 1997)}} {{for|the Chilean painter|Claudio Bravo (painter)}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2018}} {{Spanish name|Bravo|Muñoz}} {{Infobox football biography | name = Claudio Bravo | image = Chile VS. Australia (1cropped).jpg | image_size = 200 | caption = Bravo with [[Chile national football team|Chile]] in 2017 | fullname = Claudio Andrés Bravo Muñoz<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.premierleague.com/news/84136|title=Squads for 2016/17 Premier League confirmed|publisher=Premier League|date=1 September 2016|accessdate=15 September 2016}}</ref> | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1983|4|13|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Buin, Chile|Viluco]], Chile | height = {{convert|1.84|m|ftin|0|abbr=on}}<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.premierleague.com/players/5810/Claudio-Bravo/overview|title=Claudio Bravo|publisher=Premier League|accessdate=18 August 2017}}</ref> | position = [[Goalkeeper (association football)|Goalkeeper]] | currentclub = [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]] | clubnumber = 1 | youthyears1 = | youthclubs1 = [[Colo-Colo]] | years1 = 2002–2006 | clubs1 = [[Colo-Colo]] | caps1 = 123 | goals1 = 0 | years2 = 2006–2014 | clubs2 = [[Real Sociedad]] | caps2 = 229 | goals2 = 1 | years3 = 2014–2016 | clubs3 = [[FC Barcelona|Barcelona]] | caps3 = 70 | goals3 = 0 | years4 = 2016– | clubs4 = [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]] | caps4 = 25 | goals4 = 0 | totalcaps = | totalgoals = | nationalyears1 = 2004 | nationalteam1 = [[Chile Olympic football team|Chile U23]] | nationalcaps1 = 7 | nationalgoals1 = 0 | nationalyears2 = 2004– | nationalteam2 = [[Chile national football team|Chile]] | nationalcaps2 = 119 | nationalgoals2 = 0 | club-update = 13 May 2018 | nationalteam-update = 10 October 2017 | medaltemplates = {{MedalCountry|{{fb|CHI}}}} {{MedalCompetition|[[Copa América]]}} {{Medal|W|[[2015 Copa América|2015 Chile]]|}} {{Medal|W|[[Copa América Centenario|2016 USA]]|}} {{MedalCompetition|[[FIFA Confederations Cup]]}} {{Medal|RU|[[2017 FIFA Confederations Cup|2017 Russia]]|}} }} '''Claudio Andrés Bravo Muñoz''' ({{IPA-es|ˈklauðjo ˈβɾaβo}}; born 13 April 1983) is a Chilean professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[Goalkeeper (association football)|goalkeeper]] for {{English football updater|ManchesC}} club [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]] and the [[Chile national football team|Chile national team]].
He started playing with [[Colo-Colo]] and moved to [[Real Sociedad]] in 2006, appearing in 237 official games with the latter club. [[FC Barcelona|Barcelona]] signed him for €12 million in 2014, and he won the [[Treble (association football)|treble]] and the [[Ricardo Zamora Trophy|Zamora Trophy]] in [[2014–15 La Liga|his first season]]. In the summer of 2016, he moved to [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]].
Bravo is [[Chile national football team|Chile]]'s second most capped player of all time, after [[Alexis Sánchez]], with over 115 appearances since his debut in 2004, and represented the nation in two [[FIFA World Cup|World Cups]], a [[FIFA Confederations Cup]] and five [[Copa América]] tournaments. He [[Captain (association football)|captained]] his side to victory at the [[2015 Copa América|2015]] and [[Copa América Centenario|2016 editions]] of the latter competition.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.fifa.com/confederationscup/news/y=2017/m=6/news=a-closer-look-at-the-confed-cup-captains-2895407.html|title=Meet the Confed Cup captains|publisher=FIFA|date=17 June 2017|accessdate=18 June 2017|quote=He [Claudio Bravo] was a key part of the teams that competed at the 2010 and 2014 World Cups and, as captain, had the honour of raising the Copa America trophy in 2015 and 2016.}}</ref>
==Club career== ===Colo-Colo=== Bravo was born in [[Buin, Chile|Viluco]], [[Maipo Province]]. His father recognized his son's emerging talent and took him to [[Colo-Colo]]'s youth academy, and he eventually made his professional debut in 2002. There, he was given the nickname ''Cóndor Chico'', after former club goalkeeper [[Roberto Rojas]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sport.net/getting-to-know-claudio-bravo_308059#|title=Getting to know Claudio Bravo|publisher=Sport.net|last=Cernensek|first=Bostjan|date=23 January 2015|accessdate=1 September 2016}}</ref>
After an injury to [[Eduardo Lobos]], manager [[Jaime Pizarro]] gave Bravo his first chance, which would be however short-lived, as he too was injured, which prompted the subsequent signing of [[Jonny Walker (soccer)|Jonny Walker]]. He recovered in mid-2003, and with Lobos still in the sidelines he took over the starting role which he would never lose again, with his competitor eventually being sold.
In 2006, Bravo won his first title, making an acrobatic save in the ''[[Apertura and Clausura|Apertura]]'''s [[Penalty shoot-out (association football)|penalty shootout]] final win against arch-rival [[C.F. Universidad de Chile]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.ferplei.com/2013/07/se-cumplen-siete-anos-del-cara-a-cara-entre-mayer-candelo-vs-claudio-bravo-video/|title=Se cumplen siete años del cara a cara entre Mayer Candelo vs Claudio Bravo [VIDEO]|trans-title=Faceoff between Mayer Candelo and Claudio Bravo was seven years ago [VIDEO]|publisher=Ferplei|language=es|date=2 July 2013|accessdate=6 July 2015}}</ref>
===Real Sociedad=== For the [[2006–07 La Liga|2006–07 season]], Bravo signed a five-year contract with [[Real Sociedad]] in Spain,<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.realsociedad.com//document/view/spa//57947/comunicado-oficial--principio-de-acuerdo-con-bravo | title = Comunicado oficial: Principio de acuerdo con Bravo | trans-title = Official announcement: Initial agreement with Bravo | publisher = Real Sociedad | language = es | date = 28 June 2006 | accessdate = 18 August 2013}}</ref> in a reported €1.2 million deal –<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.donostiasansebastian.com/noticias3.php?id=102 | title = La Real ficha al portero Claudio Bravo | trans-title = Real sign goalkeeper Claudio Bravo | publisher = Donostia San Sebastián | language = es | date = 21 June 2006 | accessdate = 8 May 2013}}</ref> he and [[Asier Riesgo]] formed the youngest pair of goalkeepers that year in [[La Liga]]. He started on [[Substitute (association football)|the bench]], but eventually gained the battle for first-choice (29 games to nine) as the [[Basque Country (autonomous community)|Basque]] side was relegated (despite this, he finished in fifth place for the [[Ricardo Zamora Trophy]] with a goal-against average of 1.00); his league debut came on 22 October 2006, in a 0–0 away draw against [[RCD Mallorca]].<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.elmundo.es/elmundodeporte/2006/10/22/futbol/1161538421.html | title = Los palos salvan a la Real de otra derrota | trans-title = Posts prevent another Real loss | newspaper = [[El Mundo (Spain)|El Mundo]] | language = es | date = 22 October 2006 | accessdate = 21 June 2013}}</ref>
[[2007–08 Segunda División|The following season]], Riesgo reclaimed his starting position.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://archivo.marca.com/edicion/marca/futbol/2a_division/real_sociedad/es/desarrollo/1040758.html|title=Riesgo se pone 'Bravo'|trans-title=Riesgo gets all 'Brave' ("Bravo" in English)|newspaper=[[Marca (newspaper)|Marca]]|last=Badallo|first=Óscar|language=es|date=28 September 2007|accessdate=9 June 2016}}</ref> For [[2008–09 Segunda División|2008–09]], however, after a loan to the former to [[Recreativo de Huelva]], Bravo was again the starter, but Real remained in [[Segunda División]]. He was the joint-recipient of the campaign's Zamora, alongside [[David Cobeño]] of [[Rayo Vallecano]].<ref name=Perfect>{{cite news|url=http://chile.as.com/chile/2015/05/22/futbol/1432318909_260400.html|title=Claudio Bravo gana el 'Zamora' y se encamina al año perfecto|trans-title=Claudio Bravo wins the 'Zamora' and caps a perfect year|newspaper=[[Diario AS]]|last=Reyes|first=Luis|language=es|date=23 May 2015|accessdate=15 March 2016}}</ref>
On 24 January 2010, Bravo was [[Ejection (sports)|sent off]] for the first time in a loss to [[Elche CF]] at [[Anoeta Stadium]], fouling [[Óscar Trejo]] in the ninth minute, from which [[Jorge Molina Vidal|Jorge Molina]] scored a [[Penalty kick (association football)|penalty]] for the only goal of the game.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.marca.com/2010/01/24/futbol/2adivision/1264360234.html|title=Un error de Bravo deja a la Real sin liderato|trans-title=Bravo's error takes the lead from Real|newspaper=Marca|language=es|date=24 January 2010|accessdate=15 March 2016}}</ref> Three weeks later, he scored the first goal of his career, from a [[direct free kick]] against [[Gimnàstic de Tarragona]], the game's only in a home triumph;<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.europapress.es/deportes/futbol-00162/noticia-futbol-liga-adelante-cronica-gol-portero-bravo-da-victoria-real-sociedad-nastic-20100214190407.html | title = (Crónica) Un gol del portero Bravo da la victoria a la Real Sociedad ante el Nástic | trans-title = (Report) Goal by goalkeeper Bravo gives win to Real Sociedad against Nástic | publisher = [[Europa Press (news agency)|Europa Press]] | language = es | date = 14 February 2010 | accessdate = 29 May 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PPKE3CmCKy0 | title = Gol de falta del portero Bravo – Real sociedad vs Nastic! | trans-title = Free kick goal from goalkeeper Bravo – Real sociedad vs Nastic! | publisher = [[YouTube]] | language = es | date = 14 February 2010 | accessdate = 8 May 2013}}</ref> however, shortly after, he suffered a severe knee injury during Real Sociedad's 0–2 loss at [[Córdoba CF]], which rendered him unavailable for the remainder of [[2009–10 Segunda División|the season]].<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.marca.com/2010/03/30/futbol/equipos/real_sociedad/1269959532.html | title = Bravo: "Estoy triste por no poder ayudar al equipo" | trans-title = Bravo: "I'm sad for not being able to help the team" | newspaper = Marca | language = es | date = 30 March 2010 | accessdate = 8 May 2013}}</ref> He still featured in 25 matches to help his team finish champions and return to the top division, after three years.
===Barcelona=== [[File:Barça - Napoli - 20140806 - Claudio Bravo.jpg|thumb|150px|Bravo warming up for Barcelona in 2014]] Bravo joined [[FC Barcelona]] on 25 June 2014, with the four-year deal<ref name="Release">{{cite press release|url=https://www.fcbarcelona.com/football/first-team/news/2013-2014/agreement-for-claudio-bravo-to-join-fc-barcelona|title= Agreement for Claudio Bravo to join FC Barcelona|publisher=FC Barcelona|date=25 June 2014|access-date=2 July 2017}}</ref> being made effective on 1 July for a reported €12 million (£9.7 million) fee,<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.marca.com/2014/06/18/futbol/equipos/barcelona/1403127536.html | title = Bravo ya es el tercer fichaje del Barcelona | trans-title = Bravo is already Barcelona's third signing | newspaper = Marca | last = Font | first = Sergi | language = es | date = 18 June 2014 | accessdate = 21 June 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.insidespanishfootball.com/112769/real-sociedad-and-barcelona-finalise-e12-million-transfer-of-claudio-bravo/ | title = Real Sociedad and Barcelona finalise €12 million transfer of Claudio Bravo | publisher = Inside Spanish Football | last = Conn | first = Tom | date = 18 June 2014 | accessdate = 20 June 2014 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20140619165255/http://www.insidespanishfootball.com/112769/real-sociedad-and-barcelona-finalise-e12-million-transfer-of-claudio-bravo/ | archivedate = 19 June 2014 | df = dmy-all }}</ref> the fourth most expensive player ever sold by Real Sociedad after [[Darko Kovačević]], [[Xabi Alonso]] and [[Asier Illarramendi]], becoming the second Chilean to ever play for the club after [[Alexis Sánchez]] and succeeding [[Víctor Valdés]] as the first-choice. After joining, he set a Spanish League record for the club of not conceding from the start of season for 754 minutes, previously held by [[Pedro María Artola]] with 560 minutes; the streak was broken when he conceded his first goal of [[2014–15 La Liga|the season]] from the penalty spot to [[Cristiano Ronaldo]] in a 1–3 defeat to [[Real Madrid C.F.|Real Madrid]] at the [[Santiago Bernabéu Stadium|Santiago Bernabéu]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fcbarcelona.com/football/first-team/detail/article/claudio-bravo-leaves-record-at-754-minutes|title=Claudio Bravo leaves record at 754 minutes|publisher=FC Barcelona|date=25 October 2014|accessdate=7 January 2015}}</ref>
After playing 37 straight league games, Bravo was rested for the last game of the campaign against [[Deportivo de La Coruña]], with [[Jordi Masip]] starting instead. The former was named as the goalkeeper in the La Liga Team of the Season as one of six Barcelona players, including three of his defenders.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-3126163/Lionel-Messi-Cristiano-Ronaldo-lead-La-Liga-team-year-Gareth-Bale-misses-out.html|title=Cristiano Ronaldo and Lionel Messi lead La Liga team of the year... but there's no place for Gareth Bale after disappointing season|newspaper=[[Daily Mail]]|last=Skinner|first=Adam|date=17 June 2015|accessdate=24 June 2015}}</ref> He won the Zamora for the best goals against average in the competition, conceding 19 times for an average of 0.51, 0.04 off the all-time record by [[Francisco Liaño]] of Deportivo in 1994.<ref name=Zamora>{{cite web|url=http://www.fcbarcelona.com/football/first-team/detail/article/claudio-bravo-wins-first-zamora-trophy|title=Claudio Bravo wins first Zamora Trophy|publisher=FC Barcelona|date=24 May 2015|accessdate=10 July 2015}}</ref>
After [[Marc-André ter Stegen]] was preferred for Barcelona's wins in the year's [[Copa del Rey]], [[UEFA Champions League]] and [[UEFA Super Cup]], Bravo made his cup debut for the team as they won the [[2015 FIFA Club World Cup]], keeping [[Shutout|clean sheets]] in their 3–0 wins over [[Guangzhou Evergrande Taobao F.C.]] and [[Club Atlético River Plate]] in Japan.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/35141742|title=River Plate 0–3 Barcelona|publisher=[[BBC Sport]]|last=Begley|first=Emlyn|date=20 December 2015|accessdate=13 March 2016}}</ref> Interviewed by [[Esport3]] on the subject of the rotation, he said "If I were to say that I'm taking it well, I would be lying, but I accept it".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.goal.com/es-cl/news/4809/espa%C3%B1a/2015/11/02/16915842/claudio-bravo-y-su-incomodidad-con-la-rotaci%C3%B3n|title=Claudio Bravo y su incomodidad con la rotación|trans-title=Claudio Bravo and his discomfort with rotation|publisher=[[Goal (website)|Goal]]|language=es|date=2 November 2015|accessdate=26 March 2016}}</ref>
===Manchester City=== On 25 August 2016, Bravo signed a four-year deal for English club [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]] for a reported fee of £17 million.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mancity.com/news/first-team/2016/08/25/claudio-bravo-signs-for-city/1472119073317|title=Claudio Bravo signs for City|publisher=Manchester City F.C|date=25 August 2016|access-date=25 August 2016|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160825142732/http://www.mancity.com/news/first-team/2016/08/25/claudio-bravo-signs-for-city/1472119073317|archivedate=25 August 2016|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.espnfc.com/story/2937222/claudio-bravo-completes-manchester-city-transfer-from-barcelona|title=Claudio Bravo completes Manchester City transfer from Barcelona|publisher=[[ESPN FC]]|date=25 August 2016|access-date=25 August 2016}}</ref> He made his debut on 10 September in a 2–1 triumph over [[Manchester derby|local]] rivals [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]],<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/37263921|title=Manchester United 1–2 Manchester City|publisher=BBC Sport|last=McNulty|first=Phil|date=10 September 2016|accessdate=10 September 2016}}</ref> being at fault for the opposition's goal and receiving widespread criticism for his performance,<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/blog/2016/sep/10/pep-guardiola-claudio-bravo-horror-show-manchester-city-united|title=Pep Guardiola backs Claudio Bravo after serene start turns into horror show|newspaper=[[The Guardian]]|last=Jackson|first=Jamie|date=10 September 2016|accessdate=12 September 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/football/2016/09/10/claudio-bravo-brutalised-by-gary-lineker-after-nightmare-debut-i/|title=Claudio Bravo brutalised on Twitter after nightmare debut in Manchester derby|newspaper=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|last=Davis|first=Callum|date=10 September 2016|accessdate=12 September 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.espnfc.co.uk/english-premier-league/23/video/2947044/burley-claudio-bravo-poor-and-edgy|title=Burley: Claudio Bravo 'poor and edgy'|publisher=ESPN FC|date=10 September 2016|accessdate=12 September 2016}}</ref> although manager [[Pep Guardiola]] said that he had "one of the best performances I've ever seen".<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.thesun.co.uk/sport/football/1760701/manchester-derby-pep-guardiola-claims-claudio-bravos-shocker-was-one-of-the-best-performances-ive-ever-seen-after-clinching-2-1-triumph/|title=Bravo you hero – Manchester derby: Pep Guardiola claims Claudio Bravo’s shocker was ‘one of the best performances I've ever seen’ after clinching 2–1 triumph|newspaper=[[The Sun (United Kingdom)|The Sun]]|last=Shilton|first=Alec|date=10 September 2016|accessdate=12 September 2016}}</ref>
On his return to the [[Camp Nou]] on 19 October 2016, in a [[2016–17 UEFA Champions League|Champions League group stage match]], Bravo was [[Ejection (sports)|sent off]] after handling the ball outside of his area, in an eventual 0–4 loss.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/37688076|title=Barcelona 4–0 Manchester City|publisher=BBC Sport|last=Lewis|first=Aimee|date=19 October 2016|accessdate=19 October 2016}}</ref> After a number of high profile errors, including being beaten by all six shots on target in his previous two appearances for City, he was dropped to the bench in February 2017, with backup [[Willy Caballero]] replacing him;<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.espnfc.com/manchester-city/story/3052934/claudio-bravos-confidence-wont-be-affected-by-being-dropped-pep-guardiola|title=Claudio Bravo's confidence won't be hurt by being dropped – Pep Guardiola|publisher=ESPN FC|last=Smith|first=Jonathan|date=3 February 2017|access-date=8 September 2017}}</ref> having finished with the worst save success rate (54.1%) among all goalkeepers, he was named by many journalists as one of the worst signings of [[2016–17 Premier League|the season]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/who-scored-blog/2017/jan/17/claudio-bravo-worst-goalkeeper-premier-league-manchester-city|title=Claudio Bravo is not the only shot-stopper struggling in the Premier League|newspaper=The Guardian|last=Laurence|first=Martin|date=17 January 2017|access-date=8 September 2017|issn=0261-3077}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.football365.com/news/top-ten-worst-signings-of-the-premier-league-season|title=Top ten worst signings of the Premier League season|publisher=Football 365|last=Stead|first=Matthew|date=4 April 2017|access-date=8 September 2017}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.90min.com/posts/4913057-10-of-the-worst-premier-league-signings-this-season|title=10 of the worst Premier League signings this season|publisher=90 Min|last=Eyles|first=Cameron|date=24 April 2017|access-date=8 September 2017}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://bleacherreport.com/articles/2722261-manchester-city-transfer-news-pepe-reina-deal-expected-claudio-bravo-rumours|title=Manchester City transfer news: Pepe Reina deal expected, Claudio Bravo rumours|publisher=[[Bleacher Report]]|last=Clark|first=Gill|date=18 July 2017|access-date=8 September 2017}}</ref>
On 24 October 2017, after a [[2017–18 EFL Cup|0–0 home draw]] against [[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|Wolverhampton Wanderers]] in the first 120 minutes of the [[EFL Cup]] fourth-round tie, Bravo saved two penalties to give his team a 4–1 win.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2017/oct/24/manchester-city-wolves-carabao-cup-match-report|title=Claudio Bravo’s two penalty saves help Manchester City past Wolves|newspaper=The Guardian|last=Jackson|first=Jamie|date=24 October 2017|access-date=24 October 2017|issn=0261-3077}}</ref> He ruptured his [[Achilles tendon]] in training the following August, going on to be sidelined for several months.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/premier-league/claudio-bravo-injury-latest-manchester-city-news-a8500341.html|title=Manchester City goalkeeper Claudio Bravo faces lengthy spell on sidelines with Achilles injury|newspaper=[[The Independent]]|last=Critchley|first=Mark|date=20 August 2018|access-date=13 September 2018}}</ref>
==International career== [[File:Brazil vs. Chile in Mineirão 06.jpg|thumb|250px|Bravo in action against [[Brazil national football team|Brazil]] at the [[2014 FIFA World Cup]]]] Bravo represented [[Chile national football team|Chile]] at [[Chile national under-17 football team|under-17]], [[Chile national under-20 football team|under-20]] and [[Chile national under-23 football team|under-23 levels]]. He made his debut with the full side on 11 July 2004 against [[Paraguay national football team|Paraguay]] in the [[2004 Copa América]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rsssf.com/tables/2004safull.html|title=Copa América 2004|publisher=[[Rec.Sport.Soccer Statistics Foundation|RSSSF]]|accessdate=9 June 2016}}</ref> and retained his place for the rest of the [[2006 FIFA World Cup]] [[2006 FIFA World Cup qualification (CONMEBOL)|qualifiers]].
[[File:2017 Confederations Cup - Final - Claudio Bravo wins the Golden Glove.jpg|120px|thumb|left|Bravo holding the Golden Glove award at the [[2017 Confederations Cup]]]] Bravo was again called for duty in the [[2007 Copa América]] held in [[Venezuela]], where he started all four games.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.emol.com/noticias/deportes/2007/07/07/261883/el-baile-fue-ahora-en-la-cancha-brasil-goleo-6-1-a-chile.html|title=El baile fue ahora en la cancha: Brasil goleó 6–1 a Chile|trans-title=Dancing them on the pitch now: Brazil routed Chile 6–1|newspaper=[[El Mercurio]]|language=es|date=7 July 2007|accessdate=9 June 2016}}</ref> He became [[Captain (association football)|team captain]] after [[Marcelo Salas]] announced his international retirement.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://es.fifa.com/worldcup/news/y=2009/m=3/news=claudio-bravo-capitan-tiempo-completo-1037293.html|title=Claudio Bravo, capitán tiempo completo|trans-title=Claudio Bravo, full-time captain|publisher=FIFA|language=es|date=13 March 2009|accessdate=9 June 2016}}</ref> Rested for the final group game, he played three matches at the [[2011 Copa América]] as the country again reached the quarter-finals.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.marca.com/2011/07/18/futbol/futbol_internacional/america/1310948530.html|title=Venezuela también se salta el guión|trans-title=Venezuela could not care less for script as well|newspaper=Marca|last=Melero|first=Delfín|language=es|date=18 July 2011|accessdate=9 June 2016}}</ref>
In the [[2010 FIFA World Cup|2010 World Cup]] in South Africa, Bravo started in all four matches for Chile (remaining as captain), conceding five goals in an eventual 0–3 [[Single-elimination tournament|round-of-16]] loss against [[Brazil national football team|Brazil]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/world_cup_2010/matches/match_54/default.stm|title=Brazil 3–0 Chile|publisher=BBC Sport|last=Fletcher|first=Paul|date=28 June 2010|accessdate=28 June 2014}}</ref> He was also selected by new manager [[Jorge Sampaoli]] to the squad of 23 for [[2014 FIFA World Cup|the following edition]],<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/teams/chile/10810224/Chile-World-Cup-2014-squad.html|title=Chile World Cup 2014 squad|newspaper=The Daily Telegraph|date=2 June 2014|accessdate=28 June 2014}}</ref> starting all the games and conceding only four time – one by [[Australia national soccer team|Australia]], two by the [[Netherlands national football team|Netherlands]] and one by [[Brazil national football team|Brazil]] – which again ended in the same stage and at the hands of the same opponent, but in a penalty shootout.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.fifa.com/worldcup/matches/round=255951/match=300186487/match-report.html|title=Brazil through as Chile pay the penalty|publisher=FIFA|date=28 June 2014|accessdate=28 June 2014}}</ref>
On 10 October 2014, in a [[Exhibition game|friendly]] 3–0 win against [[Peru national football team|Peru]], Bravo earned his 85th [[Cap (sport)|cap]], surpassing [[Leonel Sánchez]] as Chile's most capped player of all time.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.lacuarta.com/noticias/deportiva/2014/10/64-174546-9-claudio-bravo-fue-homenajeado-por-alcanzar-85-partidos-con-la-roja.shtml|title=Claudio Bravo fue homenajeado por alcanzar 85 partidos con la Roja|trans-title=Claudio Bravo was honoured for playing 85 games with ''La Roja''|newspaper=[[La Cuarta]]|language=es|date=11 October 2014|accessdate=6 April 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150708074437/http://www.lacuarta.com/noticias/deportiva/2014/10/64-174546-9-claudio-bravo-fue-homenajeado-por-alcanzar-85-partidos-con-la-roja.shtml|archive-date=8 July 2015|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> He was the captain and played every minute as they won the [[2015 Copa América]] on home soil, their first major international honour. In [[2015 Copa América Final|the final]] against [[Argentina national football team|Argentina]] at the [[Estadio Nacional Julio Martínez Prádanos|Estadio Nacional]], he kept a clean sheet as the match finished goalless after extra time, and then saved from [[Éver Banega]] in the subsequent penalty shootout;<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2015/jul/05/chile-argentina-copa-america-final-match-report|title=Hosts Chile stun Argentina to claim first Copa América title on penalties|newspaper=The Guardian|last=Wilson|first=Jonathan|date=5 July 2015|accessdate=5 July 2015}}</ref> he was subsequently chosen for the Team of the Tournament.<ref name=Tott>{{cite web|url=http://www.ca2015.com/en/gallery/copa-america-2015---team-of-the-tournament/1nqqmzngdosa911z9l2g8k8317/slide/13|title=Copa América 2015 – Team of the tournament|publisher=[[CONMEBOL]]|date=5 July 2015|accessdate=5 July 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150707200522/http://www.ca2015.com/en/gallery/copa-america-2015---team-of-the-tournament/1nqqmzngdosa911z9l2g8k8317/slide/13|archivedate=7 July 2015|df=}}</ref>
On 24 March 2016, Bravo became the first Chilean to win his [[List of footballers with 100 or more caps|100th cap]], in a 1–2 home loss to Argentina in [[2018 FIFA World Cup qualification (CONMEBOL)|qualification]] for the [[2018 FIFA World Cup|2018 World Cup]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.goal.com/es-cl/news/4768/selecci%C3%B3n/2016/03/24/21672432/claudio-bravo-cumpli%C3%B3-100-partidos-en-la-roja|title=Claudio Bravo cumplió 100 partidos en La Roja|trans-title=Claudio Bravo completed 100 matches for ''La Roja''|publisher=Goal|language=es|date=24 March 2016|accessdate=26 March 2016}}</ref> In [[Copa América Centenario Final|the final]] of the [[Copa América Centenario]] at the [[MetLife Stadium]], against the same opponent and also on penalties, he saved [[Lucas Biglia]]'s attempt in an eventual 4–2 win.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/jun/26/chile-win-copa-america-argentina-match-report-penalty-shoot-out|title=Chile win Copa América once again as Argentina title drought continues|newspaper=The Guardian|last=Timms|first=Aaron|date=27 June 2016|accessdate=27 June 2016}}</ref>
After sitting out the first two games at the [[2017 FIFA Confederations Cup]], due to fitness problems,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.espnfc.com/chile/story/3148054/chile-goalkeeper-claudio-bravo-fit-to-face-australia-at-confederations-cup|title=Chile goalkeeper Claudio Bravo fit to face Australia at Confederations Cup|publisher=ESPN FC|date=25 June 2017|accessdate=29 June 2017}}</ref> Bravo started for the remainder of the tournament in [[Russia]], notably saving three penalty shootout attempts in the semi-finals against [[Portugal national football team|Portugal]] (0–0 after 120 minutes).<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.espnfc.com/blog/the-match/60/post/3144615/claudio-bravo-the-hero-as-chile-beat-portugal-on-penalties-in-confederations-cup-semifinal|title=Claudio Bravo superb as Chile beat Portugal on penalties to reach final|publisher=ESPN FC|date=28 June 2017|accessdate=29 June 2017}}</ref> Although his team lost out 1–0 to reigning World champions [[Germany national football team|Germany]] in [[2017 FIFA Confederations Cup Final|the final]], his performances saw him being chosen the competition's best goalkeeper.<ref name=FIFA>{{cite web|url=https://www.fifa.com/confederationscup/news/y=2017/m=7/news=awards-list-dominated-by-victorious-germans-2900157.html|title=Awards list dominated by victorious Germans|publisher=FIFA|date=2 July 2017|accessdate=3 July 2017}}</ref>
===Peru controversy=== On 13 October 2015, Peru and Chile played a [[2018 FIFA World Cup qualification (CONMEBOL)|2018 World Cup qualifier]] at the [[Estadio Nacional del Perú]]. The match ended 4–3 in favor of the latter, but offensive writings were found written in the home team's dressing room afterwards, reading: "RESPETO, POR AQUÍ PASÓ EL CAMPEÓN DE AMÉRICA" (Respect, America's champions were here). This event was criticised by the media in [[South America]],<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.infobae.com/2015/10/14/1762272-se-agrando-chile-desafiante-mensaje-el-vestuario-peru/|title=Se agrandó Chile: desafiante mensaje en el vestuario de Perú|trans-title=Chile got all tough: defiant message in Peru's dressing room|publisher=[[Infobae]]|language=es|date=14 October 2015|access-date=22 October 2018}}</ref> and two years later a witness revealed that Bravo was the one who had left this message;<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.minuto30.com/se-supo-cual-jugador-chileno-fue-el-que-rayo-el-camerino-en-peru/496616/|title=Se supo cuál jugador chileno fue el que rayó el camerino en Perú|trans-title=Chilean player who scratched dressing room in Peru identified|publisher=Minuto 30|language=es|date=12 October 2017|access-date=22 October 2018}}</ref> additionally, the player was caught on camera kicking a door after the match.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://peru.com/futbol/eliminatorias-rusia-2018/peru-vs-chile-claudio-bravo-revento-puerta-camerino-video-noticia-409614|title=Perú vs Chile: Claudio Bravo "reventó" puerta de camerino (VIDEO)|trans-title=Perú vs Chile: Claudio Bravo "exploded" dressing room door (VIDEO)|publisher=Peru.com|language=es|date=14 October 2015|access-date=22 October 2018}}</ref>
==Style of play== An authoritative presence in goal, Bravo is known for his leadership, agility, composure and shot-stopping ability, as well as his control, distribution and skill with the ball at his feet. Due to his speed when rushing off his line to anticipate opponents who have beaten the offside trap, he has been described as a ''[[Goalkeeper (association football)#Sweeper-keeper|sweeper keeper]]''; he has also been labelled as a [[Playmaker#Playmaking in other positions|playmaking goalkeeper]], due to his ability to play the ball out from the back or launch attacks from goal-kicks.<ref name="Release"/><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/37610692|title='Man City's Claudio Bravo is a playmaker not sweeper-keeper'|publisher=BBC Sport|last=Brown-Finnis|first=Rachel|date=13 October 2016|accessdate=11 December 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.espn.co.uk/football/spanish-primera-division/15/blog/post/2940293/how-marc-andre-ter-stegen-beat-claudio-bravo-for-barcelona-goalkeeper-job|title=Marc-Andre ter Stegen shows why he won the Barcelona goalkeeper job|publisher=ESPN FC|last=Hunter|first=Graham|date=30 August 2016|accessdate=2 November 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.espn.com/soccer/english-premier-league/23/blog/post/3300856/man-city-keeper-ederson-as-important-as-david-de-gea-is-for-man-united|title=Man City keeper Ederson as important as David De Gea is for Man United|publisher=ESPN FC|last=Ogden|first=Mark|date=8 December 2017|accessdate=17 January 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.thescore.com/liga/news/1289056-perfect-player-series-building-a-flawless-goalkeeper|title=Perfect player series: Building a flawless goalkeeper|publisher=The Score|last=Nesci|first=Gianluca|date=24 July 2017|accessdate=17 January 2018}}</ref>

==Early life== Walker was born in [[Sheffield]], South Yorkshire<ref name=Hugman1011/> to an English mother and Jamaican father.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/football/2016/06/09/euro-2016-one-in-three-players-could-play-for-another-country/ |title=One in three players at Euro 2016 could play for another country}}</ref> He grew up on a council estate in the [[Sharrow]] area of the city<ref name="telegraph-ambassador">{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/teams/tottenham-hotspur/8799568/Tottenham-Hotspur-v-Arsenal-Kyle-Walker-the-perfect-ambassador-for-Spurss-work-in-the-community.html |title=Tottenham Hotspur v Arsenal: Kyle Walker the perfect ambassador for Spurs's work in the community |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |location=London |first=Duncan |last=White |date=1 October 2011 |accessdate=4 May 2017}}</ref> and attended Porter Croft Infant & Junior School, followed by [[High Storrs School]] until 2006.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.thestar.co.uk/news/education/social-media-spells-end-of-sheffield-school-old-boys-social-club-1-6897306 |newspaper=The Star |location=Sheffield |title=Social media spells end of Sheffield school old boys' social club |date=16 October 2014 |accessdate=7 March 2017}}</ref>
==Club career== ===Sheffield United=== Walker joined boyhood club [[Sheffield United F.C.|Sheffield United]],<ref name=es>{{cite news |title=My dad was petrified I'd get killed on the M1, so I had to follow him to Northampton, says Kyle Walker |url=http://www.thisislondon.co.uk/standard-sport/football/article-24011485-my-dad-was-petrified-id-get-killed-on-the-m1-so-i-had-to-follow-him-to-northampton-says-kyle-walker.do |newspaper=London Evening Standard |accessdate=18 November 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111119233404/http://www.thisislondon.co.uk/standard-sport/football/article-24011485-my-dad-was-petrified-id-get-killed-on-the-m1-so-i-had-to-follow-him-to-northampton-says-kyle-walker.do |archivedate=19 November 2011 |df=dmy-all}}</ref> at the age of seven after being recommended by coach Paul Archer at [[Football Unites, Racism Divides]] and progressed through the ranks to become a regular fixture in the reserves by 2008.<ref name="telegraph-ambassador"/> In November 2008, he was allowed to join [[EFL League One|League One]] club [[Northampton Town F.C.|Northampton Town]] on a one-month [[Loan (sports)|loan]] to gain first team experience,<ref name="Northampton loan">{{cite web |title=Walker on the move |url=http://origin-www.sufc.premiumtv.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10418~1453606,00.html |publisher=Sheffield United F.C. |date=13 November 2008 |accessdate=24 November 2008}}</ref> making his debut on 15 November 2008 in a defeat by [[Oldham Athletic A.F.C.|Oldham Athletic]].<ref name="Northampton debut">{{cite web |title=Gray upset by defeat |url=http://www.ntfc.co.uk/page/MatchReaction/0,,10425~1435139,00.html |publisher=Northampton Town F.C. |date=16 November 2008 |accessdate=22 December 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120902102105/http://www.ntfc.co.uk/page/MatchReaction/0%2C%2C10425~1435139%2C00.html |archivedate=2 September 2012}}</ref> His one-month loan was later extended into January,<ref name="Northampton loan extended">{{cite web |title=Kyle extends loan |url=http://www.ntfc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10425~1494573,00.html |publisher=Northampton Town F.C. |date=22 December 2008 |accessdate=22 December 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120902102119/http://www.ntfc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0%2C%2C10425~1494573%2C00.html |archivedate=2 September 2012}}</ref> before eventually returned to Bramall Lane having played nine matches for the Cobblers.<ref>{{cite web |title=Walker returns to parent club |url=http://www.ntfc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10425~1501496,00.html |publisher=Northampton Town F.C. |date=28 December 2008 |accessdate=29 December 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090817205302/http://www.ntfc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0%2C%2C10425~1501496%2C00.html |archivedate=17 August 2009}}</ref>
Soon after returning to his parent club, Walker made his full debut for Sheffield United on 13 January 2009, starting in a third round [[FA Cup]] tie against [[Leyton Orient F.C.|Leyton Orient]].<ref name="blades debut"> {{cite web |title=Progress – On two fronts |url=http://origin-www.sufc.premiumtv.co.uk/page/Gaffersnotes/0,,10418~1520011,00.html |publisher=Sheffield United F.C. |date=14 January 2009 |accessdate=14 January 2009}}</ref> With the Blades losing a number of players to injury in the closing weeks of the season, Walker was a surprise inclusion in the starting line up for the crucial last two matches of the season, making his full league debut for the club on 25 April 2009 against [[Swansea City A.F.C.|Swansea City]].<ref name="blades league debut">{{cite news |title=No qualms over role for Walker |url=http://www.thestar.co.uk/sport/sheffield-united/No-qualms-over-role-for.5211246.jp |newspaper=The Star |location=Sheffield |date=28 April 2009 |accessdate=4 June 2009}}</ref> After two outstanding performances he retained his place as Sheffield United entered the play–offs, starting both matches against [[Preston North End F.C.|Preston North End]] and the final against [[Burnley F.C.|Burnley]] at the end of May.{{citation needed|date=April 2016}} By playing in the final, Walker became the youngest Sheffield United player ever to play at [[Wembley Stadium]].<ref name="Wembley Record">{{cite web |title=Kyle, the younger, steals record |url=http://origin-www.sufc.co.uk/page/PlayerFeatures/0,,10418~1685649,00.html |publisher=Sheffield United F.C. |date=3 June 2009 |accessdate=3 June 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130605122652/http://origin-www.sufc.co.uk/page/PlayerFeatures/0,,10418~1685649,00.html |archivedate=5 June 2013}}</ref>
===Tottenham Hotspur=== On 22 July 2009, Walker left Sheffield United to join [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]] along with fellow defender [[Kyle Naughton]] for a combined fee of £9 million, but was loaned back to United for the duration of the 2009–10 season as part of the deal.<ref name="spurs transfer">{{cite news |title=Spurs capture Naughton and Walker |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/s/sheff_utd/8144711.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=22 July 2009 |accessdate=22 July 2009}}</ref> While at [[Bramall Lane]] he was virtually ever present at right back for the first half of the season but was unexpectedly recalled back to Spurs on 1 February 2010, just before the close of the January 2010 [[transfer window]], as cover for [[Alan Hutton]] who was loaned out to [[Sunderland A.F.C.|Sunderland]] earlier the same day.<ref>{{cite news |title=Tottenham Hotspur recall Sheffield United's Walker |url=http://www.yorkshirepost.co.uk/sport/Tottenham-Hotspur-recall-Sheffield-United39s.6034450.jp |newspaper=The Yorkshire Post |location=Leeds |date=2 January 2010 |accessdate=2 February 2010}}</ref> Walker made his debut for Tottenham on Saturday 27 March 2010, in a 2–0 victory over [[Portsmouth F.C.|Portsmouth]].<ref name="spurs debut">{{cite news |title=Tottenham 2 Portsmouth 0: Peter Crouch and Niko Kranjcar pile on the pain for Pompey |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-1261128/Tottenham-2-Portsmouth-0-Peter-Crouch-Niko-Kranjcar-pile-pain-Pompey.html |newspaper=Daily Mail |date=28 March 2010 |accessdate=28 March 2010 |location=London |first=Ian |last=Ridley}}{{Unreliable source?|date=April 2017}}</ref>
[[File:Kyle Walker Spurs USA tour 2010.jpg|thumb|upright|Walker with [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]] in 2010]]
At the start of the following season, Walker went out on loan once more signing an initial six-month deal with [[Queens Park Rangers F.C.|Queens Park Rangers]] (QPR) due to injuries at the club in the right back position.<ref name="qpr loan">{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/q/qpr/8995384.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |title=Spurs defender Walker joins QPR |date=13 September 2010 |accessdate=13 September 2010}}</ref> In mid-October, his loan was extended until 3 January 2011.<ref name="extended loan">{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/q/qpr/9093535.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |title=QPR extend loan of Spurs' Walker |date=14 October 2010 |accessdate=14 October 2010}}</ref>
After he had left QPR, Walker joined [[Aston Villa F.C.|Aston Villa]] on loan until the end of the [[2010–11 Premier League|2010–11]] season.<ref name="villa loan">{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/a/aston_villa/9339872.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |title=Villa sign Spurs defender on loan |date=6 January 2011 |accessdate=6 January 2011}}</ref> He scored on his debut only nine minutes into the match against former club Sheffield United in the third round of the FA Cup in January 2011.<ref name="fa cup goal">{{cite news |title=A Houl lot of relief at Bramall Lane |url=http://www.people.co.uk/sport/football/match-reports/fa-cup-match-reports/2011/01/09/sheffield-united-1-3-aston-villa-a-houl-lot-of-relief-at-bramall-lane-102039-22835698/ |newspaper=The Sunday People |location=London |date=9 January 2011 |accessdate=6 February 2011}}</ref> At the start of February, Walker scored his first Premier League goal and first senior league goal, a 30-yard strike low into the left corner against [[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]].<ref name="prem goal">{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/eng_prem/9385528.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |title=Aston Villa 2–2 Fulham |date=5 February 2011 |accessdate=6 February 2011}}</ref> He returned to his parent club at the end of the 2010–11 season after scoring two goals in 18 appearances in all competitions for Aston Villa.
On leaving Villa Park, Walker suggested that he would be happy to return to the club the following season,<ref name="villa return">{{cite news |url=http://www.skysports.com/story/0,19528,11095_6908583,00.html |publisher=Sky Sports |title=Walker hints at Villa stay |date=1 May 2011 |accessdate=4 July 2011}}</ref> as first team opportunities were limited<ref name="spurs options">{{cite news |url=http://www.tottenhamjournal.co.uk/tottenham-hotspur/tottenham-hotspur/ten_could_leave_spurs_as_club_plan_for_september_s_25_man_squad_1_903218 |newspaper=Tottenham Journal |title=Ten could leave Spurs as club plan for September's 25-man squad |date=25 May 2011 |accessdate=4 July 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110528160305/http://www.tottenhamjournal.co.uk/tottenham-hotspur/tottenham-hotspur/ten_could_leave_spurs_as_club_plan_for_september_s_25_man_squad_1_903218 |archivedate=28 May 2011 |df=dmy-all}}</ref> but Tottenham Hotspur manager [[Harry Redknapp]] later stated that he did not wish to sell the defender.{{citation needed|date=April 2016}} Walker subsequently agreed to a contract extension at Tottenham until 2016.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.skysports.com/story/0,19528,11095_6832368,00.html |publisher=Sky Sports |title=Redknapp will not sell Walker |date=24 March 2011 |accessdate=4 July 2011}}</ref> Walker was chosen in the starting eleven for Tottenham's opening match of the 2011–12 season, against Manchester United at Old Trafford on 22 August 2011.<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/football/2011/aug/22/manchester-united-tottenham-hotspur "Manchester United v Tottenham live match report"]. ''The Guardian''. London. Retrieved 22 August 2011.</ref> On 2 October, he scored the winning goal in the [[North London derby]] against Arsenal from 25-yards out. Tottenham won the match 2–1.<ref>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/15051273 "Tottenham 2–1 Arsenal"]. BBC Sport. 2 October 2011. Retrieved 6 May 2012.</ref>
On 22 April 2012, Walker was named as the [[PFA Young Player of the Year]], beating the likes of [[Sergio Agüero]], [[Danny Welbeck]], [[Daniel Sturridge]], [[Alex Oxlade-Chamberlain]] and teammate [[Gareth Bale]] to the award, as well as being named in the [[PFA Team of the Year]].<ref name=PFA>{{cite news |title=Spurs defender Kyle Walker wins PFA Young Player award |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/17734248 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=22 April 2012 |accessdate=15 December 2017}}</ref> On 29 April, he scored a free kick from 25 yards to help Tottenham beat [[Blackburn Rovers F.C.|Blackburn Rovers]] 2–0 at [[White Hart Lane]].<ref>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/17803505 "Tottenham 2–0 Blackburn"]. BBC Sport. 29 April 2012. Retrieved 6 May 2012.</ref> On 3 May 2012, Walker was awarded with a new five-year contract, that runs until 2017.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.tottenhamhotspur.com/spurs/News/kyle-commits-to-new-deal-030512.page? |title=Kyle commits to new deal |publisher=Tottenham Hotspur F.C. |accessdate=3 May 2012}}</ref>
Walker's performance against Manchester United in March 2012 saw him at fault for two of the opposition's goals in a 3–1 defeat.{{citation needed|date=April 2016}} He began his next season in a similar vein; he was at fault for Chelsea's 4th goal in the 4–2 defeat at White Hart Lane, getting shrugged off the ball easily by Juan Mata.{{citation needed|date=April 2016}} He was ever-present in the first half of the season in the Premier League, with the exception of the 3–0 victory over Fulham at Craven Cottage; this included playing 90 minutes in the 3–2 win over Manchester United, which was Tottenham's first victory at Old Trafford in 23 years.{{citation needed|date=April 2016}}
[[File:Kyle Walker 01-09-2013 1.jpg|thumb|upright|Walker playing for Tottenham Hotspur in 2013]]
On 28 October 2013, it was announced that Walker had signed a new contract with Tottenham, keeping him at the club until 2019.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.tottenhamhotspur.com/news/new-contract-for-walker-281013/ |title=New contract for Walker |date=28 October 2013 |accessdate=28 October 2013 |publisher=Tottenham Hotspur F.C.}}</ref>
Walker was part of the team that lost 2–0 to [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] at Wembley Stadium in the [[2015 Football League Cup Final|2015 League Cup Final]] on 1 March.<ref name=2015LC>{{cite news |first=Phil |last=McNulty |title=Chelsea 2–0 Tottenham Hotspur |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/31572594 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=1 March 2015 |accessdate=16 December 2017}}</ref>
On 8 August 2015, Walker was involved in an own goal which led to Tottenham suffering a defeat in the hands of Manchester United in the season opener and it also became the first goal of the [[2015-16 Premier League|new season]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Kyler Walker's own goal gives Manchester United the win in season opener |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/33744640 |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=8 August 2015 |date=8 August 2015}}</ref>
On 20 April 2017, Walker was named as right-back in the PFA Team of the Year for the second time.<ref name=PFA1617>{{cite news |title=PFA teams of the year: Chelsea and Tottenham dominate Premier League XI |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/39648483 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=20 April 2017 |accessdate=16 December 2017}}</ref>
===Manchester City=== On 14 July 2017, Walker signed a five-year contract with Tottenham's Premier League rivals [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]],<ref>{{cite web |title=City announce signing of Kyle Walker |url=https://www.mancity.com/news/first-team/first-team-news/2017/july/kyle-walker-joins-city |publisher=Manchester City F.C. |date=14 July 2017 |accessdate=14 July 2017}}</ref> in a transfer reported to be worth an initial £45 million fee, rising to £50 million with add-ons, making it one of the [[List of most expensive association football transfers|most expensive football transfers]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Kyle Walker: Man City sign right-back from Tottenham for £45m plus add-ons |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/40598351 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=14 July 2017 |accessdate=14 July 2017}}</ref>
He made his competitive debut for City against [[Brighton & Hove Albion F.C.|Brighton]] on 12 August 2017, a game where many media outlets labelled him as the best player.<ref>{{cite news |title=Manchester City player ratings: Kyle Walker the pick in a humdrum display |url=http://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/man-city-player-ratings-brighton-13468298 |newspaper=Manchester Evening News |date=12 August 2017 |accessdate=22 August 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=£50 million man Kyle Walker impresses in debut, City see off Brighton |url=http://www.espn.co.uk/football/club/manchester-city/382/blog/post/3178393/50-million-man-kyle-walker-impresses-in-debut-manchester-city-see-off-brighton |publisher=ESPN |date=12 August 2017 |accessdate=22 August 2017}}</ref> However, during Walker's home debut for Manchester City he was sent off for two yellow card offences against Everton, which was thought to be a harsh decision by referee [[Bobby Madley]].<ref>{{cite news |title=City 1–1 Everton |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/40920114 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=21 August 2017 |accessdate=22 August 2017}}</ref> Walker was selected and part of the squad that beat Arsenal 3–0 at Wembley Stadium in the [[2018 EFL Cup Final]] to claim his and City's first trophy of the 2017–18 season.<ref name=2018LC>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/43101681 |title=Arsenal 0–3 Manchester City |first=Phil |last=McNulty |publisher=BBC Sport |date=25 February 2018 |accessdate=25 February 2018}}</ref>
==International career== Before having even made a league appearance for Sheffield United, Walker was called up to the [[England national under-19 football team|England U19s]] in February 2009.<ref name="england call up">{{cite web |title=Another young Blade earns England call |url=http://www.sufc.premiumtv.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10418~1547871,00.html |publisher=Sheffield United F.C. |date=6 February 2009 |accessdate=11 February 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120806003532/http://www.sufc.premiumtv.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10418~1547871,00.html |archivedate=6 August 2012 |df=dmy-all}}</ref> He made his début on 10 February, coming on as a second-half substitute in a 3–0 loss to [[Spain national under-19 football team|Spain U19s]].<ref name="england début">{{cite web |title=The Kyles get international cameos |url=http://www.sufc.premiumtv.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10418~1553137,00.html |publisher=Sheffield United F.C. |date=10 February 2009 |accessdate=11 February 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120805143858/http://www.sufc.premiumtv.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10418~1553137,00.html |archivedate=5 August 2012 |df=dmy-all}}</ref> Following his first run of regular Premier League starts, Walker was called up to the full [[England national football team|England]] squad in February 2011 and again in March 2011.<ref name="full england début">{{cite news |title=Fabio Capello calls up Kyle Walker for England friendly |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/9388124.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=5 February 2011 |accessdate=6 February 2011}}</ref> However, he did not feature in any of the matches played and pulled out of the squad in March due to an injury.{{cn|date=April 2017}}
At the end of the 2010–11 season, Walker was named as part of the England squad which competed in the [[2011 UEFA European Under-21 Championship]] competition in Denmark.<ref name="england u21">{{cite web |title=Squad numbers confirmed |url=http://www.thefa.com/England/mens-under-21s/News/2011/englnd-u21s-squad-numbers |publisher=The Football Association |date=7 June 2011 |accessdate=6 February 2011}}</ref> Despite the poor showing of the team who were knocked out in the first round, Walker was named in the Team of the Tournament.<ref name=TOTT>{{cite news |first=Jeremy |last=Wilson |title=Tottenham Hotspur defender Kyle Walker set to make England debut against Holland |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/teams/england/8687776/Tottenham-Hotspur-defender-Kyle-Walker-set-to-make-England-debut-against-Holland.html |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |location=London |date=7 August 2011 |accessdate=16 December 2017}}</ref>
His good form in the 2011–12 [[Premier League]] season saw him named in the England squad for a friendly against [[Spain national football team|Spain]]. On 12 November, Walker made his England debut in the 1–0 win over Spain, coming on for [[Scott Parker]] as a [[Substitute (association football)|substitute]] in the 85th minute.<ref name="bbc15693231">{{cite news |title=International friendly: England 1–0 Spain |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/15693231.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |first=Phil |last=McNulty |date=12 November 2011 |accessdate=13 November 2011}}</ref>
Walker went on to make his first start for England on 15 November, in a 1–0 win against [[Sweden national football team|Sweden]], during which he won man-of-the-match.<ref>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/15709627 "International friendly: England 1–0 Sweden"]. BBC Sport. 15 November 2011. Retrieved 3 March 2013.</ref> He missed [[UEFA Euro 2012]] because of a toe injury, suffered in a league match against Fulham.<ref>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/18081125 "England Euro 2012 squad: Ruddy, Carroll & Defoe in, Ferdinand out"]. BBC Sport. 16 May 2012. Retrieved 3 March 2013.</ref>
Walker played the first England match after Euro 2012, playing the full 90 minutes of a 2–1 win against [[Italy national football team|Italy]].<ref>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/19238374 "England 2–1 Italy"]. BBC Sport. 15 August 2012. Retrieved 3 March 2013.</ref>
He was named in the 23-man [[England national football team|England national team]] squad for the [[2018 FIFA World Cup]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/44138600 |title=England World Cup squad: Trent Alexander-Arnold in 23-man squad |publisher=BBC Sport |date=16 May 2018 |accessdate=17 May 2018}}</ref>
==Sponsorship== In December 2012, Walker signed a boot deal with [[Nike, Inc.|Nike]] to wear the T90 Laser IV which were also worn by [[Wayne Rooney]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.footballboots.co.uk/8325-kyle-walker-and-his-new-brand-nike.html |title=Kyle Walker and his new brand: Nike |publisher=FootballBoots.co.uk |accessdate=13 December 2012}}</ref> From 2009 to 2012, he wore the SX Valor, SX Flare, Stealth Pro, Speciali, Stealth Pro II, GT Pro, and GT Pro II boots by [[Umbro]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.soccerbible.com/boot-spotting/2012/12/kyle-walker-in-nike-switch-to-wear-t90/ |title=Kyle Walker in Nike Switch – To Wear T90 |date=12 December 2012 |website=soccerbible.com |accessdate=4 February 2017}}</ref>

Thank you. --> | nationalyears1 = 2002 | nationalteam1 = [[Belgium national youth football team|Belgium U16]] | nationalcaps1 = 3 | nationalgoals1 = 0 | nationalyears2 = 2002 | nationalteam2 = [[Belgium national under-17 football team|Belgium U17]] | nationalcaps2 = 2 | nationalgoals2 = 0 | nationalyears3 = 2004– | nationalteam3 = [[Belgium national football team|Belgium]] | nationalcaps3 = 87 | nationalgoals3 = 4 | medaltemplates = {{Medal|Sport|Men's [[Association football|football]]}} {{Medal|Country|{{fb|BEL}}}} {{Medal|Comp|[[FIFA World Cup]]}} {{Medal|3rd|[[2018 FIFA World Cup|2018 Russia]]|}} | club-update = 22:01, 3 January 2019 (UTC) | nationalteam-update = 07:59, 18 November 2018 (UTC) }} '''Vincent Jean Mpoy Kompany''' ({{IPA-fr|vɛ̃sɑ̃ kɔ̃pani}}; {{IPA-nl|vɪnsɛnt kɔmpani}}; born 10 April 1986) is a Belgian professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[centre back]] and [[Captain (association football)|captains]] the English club [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]], as well as playing for the [[Belgium national football team]]. In the [[2011–12 Manchester City F.C. season|2011–12 season]] he was awarded the [[Captain (association football)|captaincy]] of Manchester City, leading his club to win the [[Premier League]] that season, their first league title in 44 years.<ref>{{Cite news |title=Manchester City 3–2 QPR | url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/17973148 | date = 13 May 2012 |accessdate = 13 May 2012 | publisher = BBC Sport | first = Phil | last = McNulty}}</ref> He is also chairman of Belgium D3B Division club [[BX Brussels]].
Kompany began his professional career at [[R.S.C. Anderlecht|Anderlecht]], spending three years at the Belgian club before moving to [[Bundesliga]] club [[Hamburger SV|Hamburg]] in 2006. In the summer of 2008, at the age of 22, he completed a transfer to his current club, [[Premier League]] side Manchester City. He has since established himself as an integral part of the Manchester City squad and is one of the bargain buys of the revolutionised City era,<ref name="lee">{{Cite news |title=Exclusive – Lee: 'Kompany best centre-back to ever play for Man City' |url=http://www.talksport.co.uk/sports-news/football/premier-league/7409/7/exclusive-lee-kompany-best-centre-back-ever-play-man-city |publisher=Talksport |date=13 May 2011 |accessdate=28 August 2011}}</ref><ref name="royle">{{Cite news |title=Royle: 'Kompany has been Manchester City's best buy' |url=http://www.talksport.co.uk/radio/sports-breakfast/blog/2011-04-26/royle-kompany-has-been-manchester-citys-best-buy |publisher=Talksport |date=26 April 2011 |accessdate=28 August 2011}}</ref> blossoming into one of the [[Premier League|Premier League's]] best centre-backs. Kompany was included in the [[PFA Team of the Year|Premier League Team of the Year]] for two years in a row in 2011 and 2012 as well as being included in the 2014 team, and won the [[Premier League Player of the Season]] in 2012. Regarded as one of the best defenders in the world,<ref name="Vincent Kompany stands alone">{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/world-cup/10931612/World-Cup-2014-Vincent-Kompany-stands-alone-in-a-tournament-seriously-short-on-top-class-defenders.html|title=World Cup 2014: Vincent Kompany stands alone in a tournament seriously short on top-class defenders|publisher=The Telegraph|accessdate=22 September 2014}}</ref> he was listed 23rd in "The 100 Best Footballers in the World" by ''[[The Guardian]]''.<ref>{{cite web|title=The world's best footballers: the top 100 list|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/datablog/2012/dec/24/world-best-footballers-top-100-list|work=[[The Guardian]]|accessdate=23 March 2013|date=24 December 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=The 100 best footballers in the world – interactive|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/interactive/2012/dec/20/top-100-footballers-in-the-world-interactive|work=The Guardian|accessdate=23 March 2013|date=24 December 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://uk.soccerway.com/players/vincent-kompany/1998/ |title=V. Kompany: Summary |website=Soccerway |publisher=Perform Group |accessdate=30 June 2018}}</ref>
==Club career== ===Anderlecht=== Born in [[Uccle]], [[Brussels]], Kompany started his career at [[R.S.C. Anderlecht|Anderlecht]] at the age of 17, winning several awards including the [[Belgian Golden Shoe]] and the [[Belgian Ebony Shoe]]. Although several top European sides immediately showed interest, the player and his entourage decided to first develop a few more years at Anderlecht. "Don't you worry, I will stay here," he told Berend Scholten at UEFA.com. "At the moment the zeros in my contract are not so important. If I wanted to leave, I would have been gone already."<ref>{{cite news|first=Berend|last=Scholten|title=Anderlecht hold on to Kompany|url=http://www.uefa.com/uefachampionsleague/news/newsid=123837.html|publisher=Berend Scholten at UEFA.com|accessdate=4 November 2003}}</ref>
===Hamburg=== [[File:Kompany.jpg|thumb|left|Kompany with [[Hamburger SV|Hamburg]]]]
On 9 June 2006, however, it was announced that Kompany had been acquired by [[Hamburger SV]] for a fee of €10 million, as a replacement for fellow Belgian [[Daniel Van Buyten]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/11896/2379826/hamburg-seal-kompany-switch|title=Hamburg Seal Kompany switch|first=James|last=Pearson|publisher=Sky Sports|accessdate=18 May 2007}}</ref> In his debut season for Hamburg, he managed only six [[Bundesliga]] starts for the club before suffering an [[Achilles tendon|achilles]] injury in November that ruled him out for the rest of the season.<ref>{{cite web|title=Bundesliga stats|url=http://football.stats.com/bund/players.asp?player=41566|publisher=Footballstats|accessdate=18 May 2007|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927225022/http://football.stats.com/bund/players.asp?player=41566|archive-date=27 September 2007|dead-url=yes}}</ref> Despite his lack of involvement in the season, he was selected in a 30-man provisional squad for the [[2007 UEFA European Under-21 Football Championship]].<ref>{{cite news|first=Berend|last=Scholten|title=Belgium hope for better Kompany|url=http://www.uefa.com/competitions/under21/news/kind=1/newsid=537673.html|publisher=UEFA|date=12 May 2007|accessdate=18 May 2007|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070516114929/http://www.uefa.com/competitions/under21/news/kind=1/newsid=537673.html <!-- Bot retrieved archive --> |archivedate=16 May 2007}}</ref>
===Manchester City=== ====2008–11==== On 22 August 2008, [[Premier League]] club [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]] signed Kompany from Hamburg on a four-year contract for an undisclosed fee.<ref>{{cite news |title=Man City complete Kompany switch |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/m/man_city/7574920.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=22 August 2008 |accessdate=25 February 2018}}</ref> Two days later, Kompany made his Manchester City debut against [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]].<ref>{{cite web |title=City 3 – West Ham 0 |url=http://www.mcfc.co.uk/News/Match-reports/2008/August/City-v-West-Ham-United-24-Aug-2008 |publisher=Manchester City F.C |date=24 August 2008 |accessdate=1 October 2010}}</ref> On 28 September, Kompany scored his first goal in City's 2–1 away defeat by [[Wigan Athletic F.C.|Wigan Athletic]]. On 28 December 2008, he started the game with [[Blackburn Rovers F.C.|Blackburn Rovers]] at [[Ewood Park]] as a holding midfielder and also completed the full 90 minutes in a 2–2 draw.<ref>{{cite news |title=Wigan 2–1 Man City |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/7626945.stm |publisher=BBC Sport | date=28 September 2008 | accessdate=27 May 2010 |first=Mark |last=Ashenden}}</ref>
On 19 October 2009, Kompany signed a new five-year deal with City that would keep him at the club until 2014.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/teams/m/man_city/8314065.stm | publisher=BBC Sport | title=Kompany signs new Man City deal | date=19 October 2009 | accessdate=27 May 2010}}</ref> He scored his second league goal for the club in a 2–0 home win against [[Portsmouth F.C.|Portsmouth]]<ref>{{cite news |title=Match: Manchester City v Portsmouth |url=http://soccernet.espn.go.com/match?id=269831&cc=5901 |publisher=ESPN Soccernet|date=31 January 2010 |accessdate=1 October 2010}}</ref> and his third in a 6–1 away win against [[Burnley F.C.|Burnley]] at [[Turf Moor]].{{citation needed|date=March 2018}}
Kompany was handed the number 4 jersey for the [[2010–11 Manchester City F.C. season|2010–11 season]] after previous wearer [[Nedum Onuoha]] moved on [[loan (sports)|loan]] to [[Sunderland A.F.C.|Sunderland]]. On 14 August 2010, he started the opening [[Premier League]] fixture and received a yellow card from referee [[Andre Marriner]] against [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]] at [[White Hart Lane]] and completed the full 90 minutes alongside [[Kolo Touré]] in a 0–0 draw. Kompany put in a [[man of the match]] performance in the 1–0 home win against [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] at the [[City of Manchester Stadium]] on 25 September. On 10 November, Kompany started the [[Manchester derby]] league game with [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]] at the City of Manchester Stadium and played the full 90 minutes in a goalless draw.{{citation needed|date=March 2018}}
[[File:2011 FA Cup Final Victory Parade (4).jpg|thumb|right|Kompany holding the [[FA Cup]] during [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]]'s 2011 victory parade]]
On 12 February 2011, he started the League match against Manchester United at [[Old Trafford]] and played the full 90 minutes, partnering with [[Joleon Lescott]] in a 2–1 defeat. On 25 April, he again continued to [[Captain (association football)|captain]] the side in the absence of striker [[Carlos Tevez]] against Blackburn Rovers at Ewood Park, playing the full 90 minutes alongside Lescott in an important 1–0 victory courtesy of a late 75th-minute strike from [[Edin Džeko]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Mancini sees Kompany potential |url=http://www.skysports.com/story/0,19528,11661_6944237,00.html |publisher=Sky Sports |date=21 May 2011 |accessdate=21 May 2011 }}</ref> On 16 April, Kompany captained Manchester City's victory over main rivals Manchester United in the [[2010–11 FA Cup|FA Cup]] [[FA Cup semi-finals|semi-final]] at [[Wembley Stadium]]; City won the game 1–0. Later that day, he was named in the PFA Team of the Year alongside teammate Tevez.{{citation needed|date=March 2018}}
In the [[2011 FA Cup Final]] he started and finished the match, a 1–0 victory over [[Stoke City F.C.|Stoke City]] which delivered Manchester City's first major trophy for 35 years.<ref>{{cite news |first=Duncan |last=White |title=FA Cup final: Manchester City 1 Stoke City 0 match report |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/competitions/fa-cup/8514022/FA-Cup-final-Manchester-City-1-Stoke-City-0-match-report.html |work=The Daily Telegraph |publisher=Telegraph Media Group |date=16 May 2011 |accessdate=28 December 2017 }}</ref> At the end of the 2010–11 season, in which City qualified for the [[UEFA Champions League]] for the first time, manager [[Roberto Mancini]] praised Kompany's "incredible" season and claimed that with his attitude and mentality, Kompany can become one of the best defenders in [[UEFA|Europe]].{{citation needed|date=December 2017}}
He finished the season winning the club's 'Supporter's Player of the Year' and 'Player's Player of the Year' awards, and the [[Premier League Player of the Season]] for his outstanding performances throughout the campaign, clocking up 50 appearances in all competitions including 37 Premier League starts.{{citation needed|date=March 2018}}
====2011–14==== [[File:Manchester City v Real Madrid 21 November 2012.jpg|thumb|right|Kompany (centre) [[captain (association football)|captain]]ing City against [[Real Madrid C.F.|Real Madrid]] in 2012]]
Kompany was firmly installed as club captain for the [[2011–12 Premier League|2011–12 season]], with Tevez having expressed publicly his desire to leave the club.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.goal.com/en/news/9/english-football/2011/09/10/2658981/roberto-mancini-confirms-vincent-kompany-will-permanently|title=Roberto Mancini confirms Vincent Kompany will permanently take over Manchester City captaincy from Carlos Tevez|website=Goal|date=10 September 2011|accessdate=28 December 2017}}</ref> The opening fixture on 7 August 2011 was the [[2011 FA Community Shield|Community Shield]], which ended in a 3–2 defeat to rivals Manchester United despite City holding a two-goal lead at half-time.<ref name="BBC-Bevan">{{cite news |first=Chris |last=Bevan |title=Man City 2–3 Man Utd |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/14420151.stm |work=BBC Sport |publisher=British Broadcasting Corporation |date=7 August 2011 |accessdate=28 December 2017 }}</ref>
On 30 April 2012, Kompany scored a header from a [[David Silva]] corner in the Manchester derby; the game finished 1–0 to City and put them in first place ahead of Manchester United on goal difference with only two games of the season remaining.<ref>{{cite web | url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/17810224 | title = Man City 1–0 Man Utd | publisher = BBC Sport | date = 30 April 2012 | accessdate = 15 December 2012}}</ref> On 13 May, the final day of the Premier League season, Kompany led the team against [[Queens Park Rangers F.C.|Queens Park Rangers]] which ended in a dramatic 3–2 win, securing the league title for the club for the first time since 1968. QPR midfielder [[Joey Barton]] attempted to headbutt Kompany during the match. On 25 July, Kompany signed a six-year contract with Manchester City,<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-2179124/Vincent-Kompany-signs-year-deal-Manchester-City.html | title = Six more years! Man City captain Kompany signs new deal at Premier League champions | publisher = dailymail.co.uk | date = 26 July 2012 | accessdate = 15 December 2012}}</ref> the longest of its kind in the club's history.
After winning the curtain-raising [[2012 FA Community Shield]] 3–2 against Chelsea (Kompany lifting the trophy at the unfamiliar venue of [[Villa Park]]),<ref>{{cite news |title=Chelsea 2 Man City 3 |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/19133978 |work=BBC Sport |publisher=British Broadcasting Corporation |date=12 August 2012 |accessdate=28 December 2017}}</ref> the [[2012–13 in English football|2012–13]] season was something of a disappointment for the club as they finished bottom of their [[2012–13 UEFA Champions League group stage#Group D|Champions League group]], placed second in the league (but far behind winners Manchester United) and lost the [[2013 FA Cup Final|FA Cup Final]] 1–0 to Wigan Athletic.<ref>{{cite news |first=Daniel |last=Taylor |title=Ben Watson heads Wigan to FA Cup final glory against Manchester City |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2013/may/11/manchester-city-wigan-athletic-fa-cup |work=The Observer |publisher=Guardian News and Media |date=11 May 2013 |accessdate=28 December 2017}}</ref> Kompany played in that final, but had missed part of the league campaign due to injury, with Mancini citing his absence as a major factor in the failure to retain the title.<ref name=mistake>{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/teams/manchester-city/9933793/Manchester-City-manager-Roberto-Mancini-admits-mistake-of-not-replacing-Vincent-Kompany-cost-the-title.html|title=Manchester City manager Roberto Mancini admits 'mistake' of not replacing Vincent Kompany cost the title|newspaper=The Daily Telegraph|date=15 March 2013|accessdate=28 December 2017}}</ref>
On 2 March 2014 Kompany captained the Manchester City team that won the [[2014 Football League Cup Final|League Cup Final]], beating Sunderland 3–1.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/26311649|title=Manchester City 3–1 Sunderland|publisher=BBC|website=BBC Sport|date=2 March 2014|accessdate=28 December 2017}}</ref> On 11 May, he scored Manchester City's second goal in a 2–0 win against West Ham United as the club won the [[2013–14 Premier League]] [[List of English football champions|title]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/27273582|title=Man City 2–0 West Ham|work=BBC}}</ref>
====2014–present==== [[File:Chelsea 1 Man City 1 (16228228237).jpg|thumb|left|upright|Kompany playing for City against [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]], 2015]]
During [[2014–15 Manchester City F.C. season|2014–15]], Kompany accumulated 33 appearances in all competitions, but the club could only finish runners-up in the league and were eliminated from the domestic and continental cups at early stages, also losing out in the [[2014 FA Community Shield|Community Shield]].<ref name="guardr">{{cite news |title=Arsenal win Community Shield with victory over Manchester City – as it happened |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/live/2014/aug/10/arsenal-manchester-city-community-shield-live-wembley-mbm |first=Michael |last=Butler |work=theguardian.com |date=10 August 2014 |accessdate=28 December 2017}}</ref> In April 2015, he suffered a muscular injury during the Manchester derby which ended his campaign early,<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2015/apr/17/vincent-kompany-miss-manchester-city-season-injury|title=Vincent Kompany could miss rest of Manchester City’s season|newspaper=The Guardian|date=17 April 2015|accessdate=28 December 2017}}</ref> and this would prove to be the start of a long spell of recurring injuries (mainly muscular [[Strain (injury)|strains]]) for a player who had already endured a number of physical problems since his arrival in England.<ref name=sidelines/><ref name=mistake/><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-1360519/Roberto-Mancini-fears-Vincent-Kompany-joined-long-city-injury-list.html|title=Roberto Mancini fears Vincent Kompany has joined the long city injury list|newspaper=Daily Mail|date=25 February 2011|accessdate=28 December 2017}}</ref>
After scoring in the team's opening two [[2015–16 Premier League|Premier League]] fixtures, Kompany suffered a strain to his [[Calf (leg)|calf]] in the opening weeks of the [[2015–16 Manchester City F.C. season|2015–16 season]]<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2015/sep/18/vincent-kompany-injury-manuel-pellegrini|title=Vincent Kompany’s passion makes him prone to injury, says Manuel Pellegrini|newspaper=The Guardian|date=18 September 2015|accessdate=28 December 2017}}</ref> and lasted just minutes into his comeback match in December.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2015/dec/26/manchester-city-vincent-kompany-calf-scan-injury|title=Manchester City’s Vincent Kompany in emotional message after new injury |newspaper=The Guardian|date=26 December 2015|accessdate=28 December 2017}}</ref> in February 2016, he was fit to take part in the [[2016 Football League Cup Final|League Cup Final]] in which City defeated [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]], and was named man of the match;<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/teams/liverpool/12176573/Liverpool-vs-Manchester-City-League-Cup-final-2016-TV-channel-live.html|title= Liverpool vs Manchester City, League Cup final – live: City win the cup as hero Caballero makes three penalty saves|date=28 February 2016|work=Daily Telegraph|accessdate=28 December 2017}}</ref> however in May he was again forced off in the early stages of the [[2015–16 UEFA Champions League knockout phase#Semi-finals|Champions League semi-final]], finishing on 22 appearances and subsequently missing [[UEFA Euro 2016|Euro 2016]] with Belgium.<ref name=euro16/>
[[File:Vincent Kompany (36471172872) (2).jpg|thumb|right|Kompany training with City, 2017]] Having returned to the first team in October 2016, on 9 November Kompany withdrew from international duty with discomfort,<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/premier-league/manchester-city-news-vincent-kompany-belgium-latest-injury-setback-a7409506.html|title=Manchester City news: Vincent Kompany facing further time out after latest injury setback|newspaper=The Independent|date=10 November 2016|accessdate=28 December 2017}}</ref> and on 22 November he sustained a knee injury.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/38071191|title=Vincent Kompany: Manchester City captain out for 'weeks' with knee injury|publisher=BBC|website=BBC Sport|date=22 November 2016|accessdate=28 December 2017}}</ref> At that time, an analysis showed that he had suffered 37 injuries since joining Manchester City in 2008 and had missed over two years (878 days) in that eight-year period.<ref name=sidelines>{{cite web|url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/11661/10671231/vincent-kompanys-injuries-at-man-city-total-two-and-a-half-years-on-the-sidelines|title=Vincent Kompany's injuries at Man City total two-and-a-half years on the sidelines |publisher=Sky Sports|date=25 November 2016|accessdate=28 December 2017}}</ref> By April 2017 he had recovered, and scored in a victory over Tottenham Hotspur, commenting on his issues that "The main thing is self-belief and experience". Manager [[Pep Guardiola]] kept Kompany in the team for the [[2016–17 FA Cup#Semi-finals|FA Cup semi-final]], and he played the entirety of the match which went to [[Overtime (sports)#Association football (soccer)|extra time]]; City lost the tie to eventual winners [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]],<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/39612222|title=Arsenal 2–1 Manchester City|publisher=BBC|website=BBC Sport|date=23 April 2017|accessdate=28 December 2017}}</ref> finishing [[2016–17 Manchester City F.C. season|2016–17]] without a trophy. Kompany appeared just 15 times during the campaign, although his continued importance to the team was evidenced by the fact he would always return to the starting line-up as soon as he was fit.
