September 2018 (UTC) }} '''Benjamin Mendy''' ({{IPA-fr|bɛ̃.ʒa.mɛ̃ mɑ̃.di}}; born 17 July 1994) is a French professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[left back]] for {{English football updater|ManchesC}} club [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]] and the [[France national football team|French national team]].
After coming through [[Le Havre AC|Le Havre]]'s youth academy, Mendy began his playing career with the club's reserve side in 2010, eventually being promoted to the first team a year later. He remained with the club until 2013, when he joined [[Ligue 1]] side [[Olympique de Marseille|Marseille]]. Mendy spent the next three seasons with ''Les Olympiens'' before leaving for [[AS Monaco FC|Monaco]], with whom he won the [[List of Ligue 1 champions|national championship]] in [[2016–17 Ligue 1|2016–17]]. In the summer of 2017, Mendy moved to the English club Manchester City on a then world-record transfer fee for a defender. He subsequently won the Premier League in [[2017–18 Manchester City F.C. season|his first season]] in England.
Mendy made his senior debut for France in 2017 after previously being [[Cap (sport)|capped]] by [[France national youth football team|France youth teams]] at [[France national under-16 football team|under-16]], [[France national under-17 football team|under-17]], [[France national under-18 football team|under-18]], [[France national under-19 football team|under-19]] and [[France national under-21 football team|under-21]] levels. He was chosen in France's squad for the [[2018 FIFA World Cup|2018 World Cup]] which they won.
==Club career== ===Le Havre=== On 24 July 2011, Mendy signed his first professional contract, a three-year contract with [[Ligue 2]] club [[Le Havre AC|Le Havre]].<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.hac-foot.com/actualite/benjamin-mendy-signe-pro-pour-3-saisons.html | title = Benjamin Mendy signe pro pour 3 saisons | date = 24 July 2011 | work = [[Le Havre AC]] | accessdate = 9 August 2011 | language = French}}</ref> Mendy made his professional debut on 9 August 2011 in the team's 2–1 [[2011–12 Coupe de la Ligue|Coupe de la Ligue]] second round defeat to [[Amiens SC|Amiens]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Amiens v. Le Havre Report |url=http://new.lfp.fr/coupeLigue/feuille_match/75258 |work=[[Ligue de Football Professionnel]] |date=9 August 2011 |accessdate=9 August 2011 |language=French |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120916073327/http://new.lfp.fr/coupeLigue/feuille_match/75258 |archivedate=16 September 2012 |df=dmy }}</ref>
===Marseille=== On 8 July 2013, Mendy signed for [[Ligue 1]] side [[Olympique de Marseille]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Transfer news: Marseille agree deal for Sunderland target Benjamin Mendy|url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/11695/8814061/transfer-news-marseille-agree-deal-for-sunderland-target-benjamin-mendy|website=Sky Sports|date=8 July 2013 |accessdate=16 March 2017 }}</ref> Mendy was signed by manager [[Élie Baup]], who led Marseille to a second place finish and qualification for the [[2013–14 UEFA Champions League]] in the previous season.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.africatopsports.com/2013/07/13/elie-baup-benjamin-mendy-est-un-joueur-davenir/ |title=ELIE BAUP : " BENJAMIN MENDY EST UN JOUEUR D'AVENIR " |work=Africa Top Sports |first=Isidore |last=Akouete |date=13 July 2013 |language=fr}}</ref> He made his club and Ligue 1 debut on 11 August against [[En Avant de Guingamp|Guingamp]], and scored his first goal for Marseille on 24 September against [[AS Saint-Étienne|Saint-Étienne]]. Mendy was in the squad for all six [[2013–14 UEFA Champions League#Group stage|group stage]] matches, and made his European debut on 1 October at [[Borussia Dortmund]]. However, Marseille lost all their group stage matches while falling out of the competition, and Baup was sacked in favor of former club manager [[José Anigo]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/25282768 |title=Elie Baup sacked as Marseille manager |work=BBC Sport |date=7 December 2013}}</ref> Mendy was sparingly used toward the end of the season by Anigo, and made just one start in Marseille's final fourteen games. His performance in the start, against [[Lille OSC|Lille]] on 20 April 2014, was criticized by former Marseille left-back [[Éric Di Meco]], who claimed he would "eat a rat" if Mendy ever made the [[France national football team|French national team]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.lephoceen.fr/infos-om/decla/di-meco-prend-les-paris-contre-mendy-l-ancien-defenseur-marseillais-tacle-benjamin-mendy-125264 |title=Di Meco prend les paris contre Mendy |work=Le Phocéen |date=22 April 2014 |language=fr}}</ref> After the season, Mendy was included on the 40-man shortlist for the 2014 [[Golden Boy (award)|Golden Boy]] award.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2014/oct/30/five-english-players-shortlist-golden-boy |title=Five English players on 40-man shortlist for Golden Boy award |work=The Guardian |first=Ed |last=Aarons |date=30 October 2014}}</ref>
Mendy developed his game the following season under Argentinian manager [[Marcelo Bielsa]], as Mendy claimed Bielsa had "given back to him the strength and aggressiveness lost last year."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.leparisien.fr/espace-premium/sports/benjamin-mendy-en-toute-insouciance-20-12-2014-4388823.php |title=Benjamin Mendy en toute insouciance |work=[[Le Parisien]] |date=20 December 2014 |language=fr}}</ref> Mendy made 33 starts in the league in the [[2014–15 Ligue 1|2014–15]] campaign, getting 6 assists as well as Marseille qualified for the [[2015–16 UEFA Europa League#Group stage|Europa League]]. On 23 September 2015, Mendy was shown a straight red card shortly after coming on as a substitute against [[Toulouse FC|Toulouse]], after he committed a professional foul on Toulouse's [[Jean-Daniel Akpa-Akpro]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.espnfc.com/report?gameId=424679 |title=Toulouse 1-1 Marseille |work=ESPN FC |author=PA Sport |date=23 September 2015}}</ref> Mendy would be given a two-match ban, and later missed a further 13 games for Marseille after picking up a hamstring injury against [[SM Caen|Caen]] in the [[2015–16 Coupe de France#Round of 64|Coupe de France]] on 3 January 2016.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ligue1.com/ligue1/article/mendy-joins-om-injury-list.htm |title=MENDY JOINS OM INJURY LIST |work=Ligue 1 |date=6 January 2016}}</ref>
Mendy played for five different managers in three seasons at the [[Stade Vélodrome]]. He made 101 competitive appearances with the club and had 14 assists to his name.
===Monaco=== On 22 June 2016, Olympique de Marseille's Ligue 1 rivals [[AS Monaco FC|Monaco]] announced that they had signed Mendy on a five-year contract.<ref>{{cite news |title=Benjamin Mendy signs on a five-year contract|url=http://www.asmonaco.com/en/article/benjamin-mendy-signs-on-a-five-year-contract-7293.html|website=AS Monaco|date=22 June 2016 |accessdate=22 June 2016 }}</ref> Mendy made his debut for the club in the first leg of the Champions League [[2016–17 UEFA Champions League#Third qualifying round|third round]] against Turkish side [[Fenerbahçe S.K. (football)|Fenerbahçe]] on 27 July. On 18 December against [[Olympique Lyonnais|Lyon]] in Ligue 1, Mendy was shown a red card for kicking at the backside of Lyon midfielder [[Corentin Tolisso]]. This was his second dismissal of the season after he was sent off in the [[2016–17 UEFA Champions League#Play-off round|play-off round]] of the Champions League against [[Villarreal CF|Villarreal]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-4046616/Monaco-1-3-Lyon-Benjamin-Mendy-sees-red-Alexandre-Lacazette-caps-fine-away-win-Principality.html |title=Monaco 1-3 Lyon: Benjamin Mendy sees red as Alexandre Lacazette caps fine away win in the Principality |work=Daily Mail |first=Ben |last=Grounds |date=18 December 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.thesun.co.uk/sport/1634245/mendy-says-sorry-after-being-sent-off-in-monacos-champions-league-play-off-first-leg-victory-2-1-against-villarreal/ |title=Mendy says 'sorry' after being sent off in Monaco's Champions League play-off first leg victory (2-1) against Villarreal |work=The Sun |first=Dylan |last=Legrand |date=18 August 2016}}</ref> Mendy was banned five matches for the incident, later reduced to four as he made his return against [[FC Lorient|Lorient]] on 22 January 2017.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://uk.reuters.com/article/uk-soccer-france-mon-mendy/as-monaco-defender-mendy-banned-for-five-matches-idUKKBN14C1O0 |title=AS Monaco defender Mendy banned for five matches |work=Reuters |first=Silvia |last=Recchimuzzi |date=23 December 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.lequipe.fr/Football/Actualites/Benjamin-mendy-de-retour-de-suspension-avec-monaco/770940 |title=Benjamin Mendy de retour de suspension avec Monaco |work=[[L'Équipe]] |date=21 January 2017 |language=fr}}</ref>
On 4 February, Mendy [[assist (football)|assisted]] two of Monaco's goals by [[cross (football)|crossing]] the ball to the scorers [[Valère Germain]] and [[Radamel Falcao]] in their 3–0 Ligue 1 home win over [[OGC Nice]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.ligue1.com/ligue1/article/falcao-at-the-double-as-monaco-power-on.htm|title=Falcao at the double as Monaco power on|date=4 February 2017|work=www.ligue1.com}}</ref> Mendy scored his first goal for Monaco in the [[2016–17 Coupe de France#Round of 16|Coupe de France]] against former club Marseille on 1 March. The goal, scored in extra time, gave Monaco a 3–2 lead, as Mendy also provided two assists in the 4–3 victory.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.eurosport.com/football/coupe-de-france/2016-2017/monaco-down-marseille-in-french-cup-thriller-psg-through_sto6077251/story.shtml |title=Monaco down Marseille in French Cup thriller, PSG through |work=Eurosport |author=Reuters |date=2 March 2017}}</ref> Monaco made a run to the semi-finals of the Champions League, and Mendy provided 4 assists in the campaign before they were eliminated by [[Juventus F.C.|Juventus]].
Mendy was a key part of Monaco's [[2016–17 Ligue 1]] championship season, making 24 starts in the league for ''Les Monégasques'' under manager [[Leonardo Jardim]]. Monaco scored a league-leading 107 goals during the season, and Mendy was noted along with fellow [[Defender (association football)#Full-back|full-back]] [[Djibril Sidibé (footballer, born 1992)|Djibril Sidibe]] for their forward play.<ref name="reuters">{{cite web |url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/uk-soccer-france-amo-ste/monaco-claim-first-title-in-17-years-with-st-etienne-win-idUKKCN18D2ON |title=Monaco claim first title in 17 years with St Etienne win |work=Reuters |first=Julien |last=Pretot |date=17 May 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://bleacherreport.com/articles/2707470-monaco-win-2016-17-ligue-1-title-after-2-0-win-vs-saint-etienne |title=Monaco Win 2016-17 Ligue 1 Title After 2-0 Win vs. Saint-Etienne |work=Bleacher Report |first=Matt |last=Jones |date=17 May 2017}}</ref> On 16 May, Mendy was named to the [[Trophées UNFP du football|2017 UNFP Team of the Year]], along with 5 of his teammates.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://frenchfootballdaily.com/2017/05/ligue-1-team-of-the-season-2016-17-official-unfp-team-of-the-year-2017/ |title=Ligue 1 Team of the Season 2016-17 Official- UNFP Team of the Year 2017 |work=French Football Daily |date=16 May 2017}}</ref> The next day, Monaco clinched the Ligue 1 title against [[AS Saint-Étienne|Saint-Étienne]] on the penultimate day of the season, their first in 17 seasons in what would be Mendy's final game with the club.<ref name="reuters"/> After the season, Mendy was part of the exodus away from the [[Stade Louis II]] that included starlets [[Bernardo Silva]], [[Tiemoué Bakayoko]], and later [[Kylian Mbappé]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2017/jul/25/monaco-benjamin-mendy-tiemoue-bakayoko-bernardo-silva-ligue-1 |title=How will Monaco cope after losing so many of their title-winning stars? |work=The Guardian |first=Eric |last=Devin |date=25 July 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.espnfc.com/story/3190925/kylian-mbappe-signs-for-paris-saint-germain-from-monaco |title=Monaco star Kylian Mbappe, 18, follows Neymar in moving to PSG in huge deal |work=ESPN FC |first=Jonathan |last=Johnson |date=31 August 2017}}</ref>
===Manchester City=== On 24 July 2017, it was announced that [[Premier League]] side [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]] had signed Mendy on a five-year contract,<ref>{{Cite news|title=Man City sign Benjamin Mendy|url=https://www.mancity.com/news/first-team/first-team-news/2017/july/benjamin-mendy-signs-manchester-city|date=24 July 2017 |accessdate=24 July 2017|publisher=Manchester City Official Website}}</ref> for a fee reported to be £52m.<ref>{{cite web|title=Benjamin Mendy: Man City sign Monaco defender for £52m|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/40691689|publisher=[[BBC Sport]]|accessdate=24 July 2017}}</ref> The transfer fee eclipsed the previous record for a defender, set 10 days prior by City on teammate [[Kyle Walker]]. On 23 September, Mendy sustained an injury against [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]], hurting his right knee on a challenge against Palace forward [[Andros Townsend]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://bleacherreport.com/articles/2725005-benjamin-mendy-suffers-knee-injury-vs-crystal-palace |title=Benjamin Mendy Suffers Knee Injury vs. Crystal Palace |work=Bleacher Report |first=Tom |last=Sunderland |date=23 September 2017}}</ref> The club later confirmed that Mendy had ruptured the [[anterior cruciate ligament]] in his knee, and he underwent surgery in [[Barcelona]] on 29 September.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2017/sep/28/benjamin-mendy-manchester-city-rupture-cruciate-ligament-injury |title=Manchester City confirm Benjamin Mendy has ruptured ACL in right knee |work=The Guardian |first=Jamie |last=Jackson |date=28 September 2017}}</ref> Despite a lack of game time, Mendy became popular with Manchester City supporters due to a series of well-received [[social media]] posts.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-4899050/Benjamin-Mendy-Football-s-new-king-social-media.html|title=Benjamin Mendy: Football's new king of social media|work=Mail Online|access-date=10 May 2018}}</ref> He returned from injury on 22 April 2018 as a 75th minute substitute for [[Fabian Delph]] in a game against [[Swansea City A.F.C.|Swansea City]] at the [[City of Manchester Stadium]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/premier-league/manchester-city-premier-league-benjamin-mendy-injury-return-fabian-delph-form-a8319171.html|title=Benjamin Mendy eager to City place back as he hails Fabian Delph's form in his absence|publisher=}}</ref> This appearance gave him the minimum 5 league games required to receive a [[Premier League]] winners' medal. In the 2018/19 season, Mendy played in 10 of the first 12 [[Premier League]] games for [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]], assisting 5 goals in the process.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.premierleague.com/players/5575/Benjamin-Mendy/stats?co=1&se=210|title=Benjamin Mendy Statistics {{!}} Premier League|website=www.premierleague.com|language=en|access-date=2018-11-15}}</ref> On the 14th November 2018, just days after the 3-1 win against [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]], it was announced Mendy had once again undergone surgery<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.mancity.com/news/first-team/first-team-news/2018/november/man-city-benjamin-mendy-injury-news-latest-france|title=Mendy undergoes knee surgery|website=MCFC|language=en|access-date=2018-11-15}}</ref> in [[Barcelona]] for a [[cartilage]] problem in his left knee, and he was expected to be out for 12 weeks.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Lee |first1=Sam |title=Mendy out for up to three months with latest knee injury |url=https://www.goal.com/en-gb/news/manchester-city-defender-mendy-out-for-12-weeks/185ptg2oz2hdy10i2lvv43k42u |website=[[Goal (website)|Goal]] |accessdate=23 November 2018}}</ref>
==International career== [[File:Benjamin Mendy World Cup Trophy.jpg|200px|thumb|Mendy (centre) holding the [[FIFA World Cup Trophy]]]]
===Youth=== Mendy is a [[France national youth football team|French youth international]] having represented his nation at [[France national under-16 football team|under-16]] and [[France national under-17 football team|under-17]] level. In 2011, he was a part of the under-17 team that reached the quarter-finals at the [[2011 FIFA U-17 World Cup|2011 U-17 World Cup]].
===Senior=== Mendy was called up to the senior [[France national football team|France]] squad for the first time to face [[Luxembourg national football team|Luxembourg]] and [[Spain national football team|Spain]] in March 2017.<ref>{{cite news|title=Monaco star Mbappé given maiden France call-up|url=http://www.goal.com/en/news/8/main/2017/03/16/33699112/monaco-star-mbappe-given-maiden-france-call-up?ICID=HP_BN_3|accessdate=16 March 2017|publisher=goal.com|date=16 March 2017}}</ref> He made his debut on 25 March 2017 against the former, playing the whole game in a 3–1 [[2018 FIFA World Cup qualification (UEFA)|2018 World Cup qualification]] away win.<ref name="soccerway1">{{cite web|url=https://int.soccerway.com/matches/2017/03/25/europe/wc-qualifying-europe/luxembourg/france/2116195/|title=Luxembourg vs. France – 25 March 2017 – Soccerway|publisher=soccerway.com|accessdate=25 March 2017}}</ref>
On 17 May 2018, he was called up to the French squad for the [[2018 FIFA World Cup|2018 World Cup]] in [[Russia]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/12025/11376691/alexandre-lacazette-and-anthony-martial-on-standby-for-france-world-cup-squad-and-dimitri-payet-out |title=Alexandre Lacazette and Anthony Martial on standby for France World Cup squad and Dimitri Payet out |date=21 May 2018 |publisher=Sky Sports |author=Andy Charles |accessdate=18 September 2018}}</ref>

{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2018}} {{Infobox football biography |name = Riyad Mahrez |image = Algérie - Arménie - 20140531 - Riyad Mahrez.jpg |image_size = 200 |caption = Mahrez lining up for [[Algeria national football team|Algeria]] in 2014 |fullname = Riyad Karim Mahrez<ref name="2017 Africa Cup of Nations Squad List - Algeria">{{cite web | title = 2017 Africa Cup of Nations Squad List – Algeria | url = http://www.cafonline.com/Portals/0/Total%20AFCON%202016/CAN%20Gabon%20Squad%20lists.pdf | publisher = CAF | format = PDF | accessdate = 10 January 2017}}</ref> |birth_date = {{birth date and age|1991|2|21|df=y}}<ref name=PremProfile/> |birth_place = [[Sarcelles]], France |height = 1.79 m<ref name=PremProfile/> |position = [[Midfielder#Winger|Winger]] |currentclub = [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]] |clubnumber = 26 |youthyears1 = 2004–2009 |youthclubs1 = AAS Sarcelles |years1 = 2009–2010 |clubs1 = [[Quimper Kerfeunteun F.C.|Quimper]] |caps1 = 27 |goals1 = 1 |years2 = 2010–2013 |clubs2 = [[Le Havre AC|Le Havre II]] |caps2 = 60 |goals2 = 24 |years3 = 2011–2014 |clubs3 = [[Le Havre AC|Le Havre]] |caps3 = 60 |goals3 = 6 |years4 = 2014–2018 |clubs4 = [[Leicester City F.C.|Leicester City]] |caps4 = 158 |goals4 = 42 |years5 = 2018– |clubs5 = [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]] |caps5 = 22 |goals5 = 6 |nationalyears1 = 2014– |nationalteam1 = [[Algeria national football team|Algeria]] |nationalcaps1 = 43 |nationalgoals1 = 10 |club-update = 08:42, 3 March 2019 (UTC) |ntupdate = 18:33, 18 November 2018 (UTC) }} '''Riyad Karim Mahrez''' ({{lang-ar|رياض كريم محرز}}; born 21 February 1991) is a professional [[association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[Midfielder#Winger|winger]] for {{English football updater|ManchesC}} club [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]] and the [[Algeria national football team|Algerian national team]].
Mahrez began his career as a youth player for French club AAS Sarcelles. He turned professional in 2009 with [[Quimper Kerfeunteun F.C.|Quimper]], where he played for only one season before moving to [[Le Havre AC|Le Havre]], spending a total of three years with them, initially playing for their reserve team and then becoming a first-team regular. In January 2014, Mahrez signed for English side [[Leicester City F.C.|Leicester City]], helping them win the [[EFL Championship|Championship]] and promotion to the Premier League at the end of his first season. In the 2015–16 season he was the [[Algerian Footballer of the Year]], the [[PFA Players' Player of the Year]], and was a member of the Premier League [[PFA Team of the Year]] as he helped Leicester City win the [[2015–16 Premier League|Premier League]].
Born in France, Mahrez made his international debut for [[Algeria national football team|Algeria]] in 2014 and represented them at the [[2014 FIFA World Cup]] and both the [[2015 Africa Cup of Nations|2015]] and [[2017 Africa Cup of Nations|2017]] [[Africa Cup of Nations]]. In 2016 he was named [[Confederation of African Football|CAF]]'s [[African Footballer of the Year]].
==Early life== Mahrez was born in [[Sarcelles]], France, to an Algerian father and a mother of Algerian and Moroccan descent.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.djazairess.com/fr/letemps/140838|title=Riyad Mahrez : "On a une équipe capable de faire de belles choses"|date=10 January 2015|accessdate=6 March 2016|language=French|publisher=DjaZairess}}</ref> His father Ahmed was from [[Beni Snous]], [[Tlemcen District]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lebuteur.com/article/detail?id=33412|title=Mahrez honoré à Tlemcen|date=4 June 2015|accessdate=28 January 2016|language=French|publisher=El Heddaf}}</ref> Growing up, Mahrez would regularly spend his holidays in Algeria.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lebuteur.com/article/detail?id=4572&titre=comment-la-faf-a-chipe-mahrez-au-maroc|title=Comment la FAF a chipé Mahrez au Maroc|date=9 May 2014|accessdate=10 June 2014|language=French|publisher=Le Buteur}}</ref><ref name=doyle>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2015/sep/12/leicester-city-riyad-mahrez-father-dream-algeria-world-cup|title=Leicester City's Riyad Mahrez is fast fulfilling his late father's dreams|date=12 September 2015|accessdate=14 September 2015|author=Paul Doyle|publisher=The Guardian}}</ref> His childhood friends included fellow footballers such as [[Wissam Ben Yedder]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Ben Yedder's unquestionable self-belief driving him to reach new heights|url=https://www.uefa.com/insideuefa/about-uefa/news/newsid=2518566.html|accessdate=23 November 2017|publisher=UEFA|date=12 December 2017}}</ref>
Mahrez's father had played football in Algeria.<ref name=doyle/> When Mahrez was fifteen, his father died of a heart attack. He reflected that "I don't know if I started to be more serious but after the death of my dad things started to go for me. Maybe in my head, I wanted it more".<ref name=doyle/>
==Club career==
===Early career=== Although often overlooked by teams due to his slender build, Mahrez developed ball skills that brought him attention.<ref name=doyle/>
He joined AAS Sarcelles in 2004.<ref name = "journey">{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/35688719|title=Riyad Mahrez: Leicester forward's journey to top of Premier League|date=10 March 2016|accessdate=10 March 2016|author=Steve Crossman|publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref>
In 2009, Mahrez joined [[Championnat de France amateur|CFA]] side [[Quimper Kerfeunteun F.C.|Quimper]] from AAS Sarcelles, making 22 appearances and scoring 2 goals in his first season with the club.<ref name="Quimper">{{cite web|url=http://stat2foot.com/qrclubs/quimper0910.htm |language=French |title=QUIMPER 17e CFA Groupe D |publisher=Stat2foot.com |accessdate=11 January 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140111075652/http://stat2foot.com/qrclubs/quimper0910.htm |archivedate=11 January 2014 }}</ref> While playing for Quimper he lived with [[Mathias Pogba]].<ref name = "journey"/>
He joined [[Le Havre AC|Le Havre]] in 2010, turning down offers from leading French teams [[Paris Saint-Germain]] and [[Olympique de Marseille|Marseille]] to join them, being enticed by their youth system.<ref name=doyle/> He initially played for their reserve team, Le Havre II, before going on to play 60 times and score 6 goals for the first team in the French [[Ligue 2]] from 2011 until leaving in January 2014.<ref name = "SW"/><ref>{{LFP|id=mahrez-riyad|name=Riyad Mahrez}}</ref> He criticised Ligue 2 for what he saw as a reliance on defence and teams aiming for a goalless draw in every match.<ref name=doyle/>
===Leicester City=== [[File:Riyad Mahrez.jpg|thumb|right|Mahrez playing for Leicester in 2014]] [[File:Mahrez free kick 1 (16476351346).jpg|thumb|303px|Mahrez taking a free kick away to [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] in February 2015.]]
====2013–14 season==== While Mahrez was playing for Le Havre, English [[EFL Championship|Championship]] club [[Leicester City F.C.|Leicester City]]'s scout [[Steve Walsh (scout)|Steve Walsh]] was monitoring teammate [[Ryan Mendes]], but was instead impressed by Mahrez.<ref>{{cite news|title=Leicester City star Riyad Mahrez not target of original scouting mission says head of recruitment|url=http://www.leicestermercury.co.uk/Riyad-target-scouting-mission/story-28029571-detail/story.html|accessdate=26 April 2016|work=Leicester Mercury|date=22 October 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151129020313/http://www.leicestermercury.co.uk/Riyad-target-scouting-mission/story-28029571-detail/story.html|archivedate=29 November 2015|df=}}</ref> Mahrez had never heard of Leicester, whom he initially presumed to be a rugby club.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Brewin|first1=Joe|title=Riyad Mahrez: The street-schooled dreamer whose ambition knew no limits|url=http://www.fourfourtwo.com/features/riyad-mahrez-street-schooled-dreamer-whose-ambition-knew-no-limits|accessdate=1 September 2016|work=FourFourTwo|date=25 April 2016}}</ref> On 11 January 2014, he signed a three-and-a-half-year contract.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lcfc.com/news/article/110114-riyad-mahrez-signs-for-leicester-city-1287938.aspx|title=Riyad Mahrez Signs For Leicester City|date=11 January 2014|accessdate=11 January 2014|publisher=Leicester City F.C.}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/25639726|title=Transfer window: Riyad Mahrez joins Leicester from Le Havre|date=11 January 2014|accessdate=13 January 2014|publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref> His friends and family were initially sceptical of a move to English football due to its physical nature, believing that his style of play would be more suited to Spain.<ref name=doyle/>
Mahrez made his debut on 25 January 2014, coming on in the 79th minute as a substitute replacing fellow winger [[Lloyd Dyer]], in the 2–0 win against [[Middlesbrough F.C.|Middlesbrough]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/25789370|title=Leicester 2 – 0 Middlesbrough|date=25 January 2014|accessdate=25 January 2014|publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref> After making four substitute appearances for Leicester, including scoring his first goal for the club, an 82nd-minute equaliser against [[Leicester City F.C.–Nottingham Forest F.C. rivalry|local rivals]] [[Nottingham Forest F.C.|Nottingham Forest]], manager Nigel Pearson announced in February 2014 that he thought Mahrez was ready to start games.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/26278839|title=Riyad Mahrez: Nigel Pearson says winger ready to start games|date=21 February 2014|accessdate=23 February 2014|publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref> Leicester ended [[2013–14 Football League Championship|the season]] as winners of the Championship, returning to the Premier League for the first time in ten years.<ref name=champ>{{cite news|title=Leicester City promoted to Premier League after 10-year absence|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/26906091|accessdate=20 December 2015|publisher=BBC Sport|date=5 April 2014}}</ref>
====2014–15 season==== Mahrez made his Premier League debut on 16 August 2014, and scored his first goal in the division on 4 October 2014 in a 2–2 draw with [[Burnley F.C.|Burnley]].<ref name = "SB"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.leicestermercury.co.uk/Leicester-City-news-Unknown-Riyad-Mahrez-making/story-23059629-detail/story.html|title='Unknown' Riyad Mahrez making impressive strides, says Nigel Pearson|date=8 October 2014|accessdate=16 October 2014|publisher=Leicester Mercury|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141020150217/http://www.leicestermercury.co.uk/Leicester-City-news-Unknown-Riyad-Mahrez-making/story-23059629-detail/story.html|archivedate=20 October 2014|df=}}</ref> Mahrez was part of the Leicester team that won seven of its final nine matches of the season to avoid relegation to the Football League. He scored both goals in a 2–0 defeat of [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]] on 9 May<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/32561831|title=Leicester 2–0 Southampton}}</ref> and ended [[2014–15 Leicester City F.C. season|the season]] with four goals and three assists from 30 appearances.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://m.premierleague.com/en-gb/players/playerprofile.html/riyad-mahrez|title=Riyad Mahrez|accessdate=20 December 2015|work=Premier League|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151222111631/http://m.premierleague.com/en-gb/players/playerprofile.html/riyad-mahrez|archivedate=22 December 2015|df=}}</ref>
====2015–16 season==== He signed a new four-year contract with Leicester in August 2015.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/33789418|title=Riyad Mahrez: Leicester City winger signs new contract|date=5 August 2015|accessdate=6 August 2015|publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref> On 8 August 2015, Mahrez scored two goals in the season opener against [[Sunderland A.F.C.|Sunderland]] in a 4–2 home win.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://int.soccerway.com/matches/2015/08/08/england/premier-league/leicester-city-fc/sunderland-association-football-club/2043050/|title=Leicester City 4–2 Sunderland|date=8 August 2015|accessdate=10 August 2015|publisher=Soccerway}}</ref> He was later described as the club's "match winner" by captain [[Wes Morgan]], following "superb form" which saw him score four goals in the first three games of the season.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.leicestermercury.co.uk/t-rely-Mahrez-time-ndash-Wes/story-27760222-detail/story.html|title=We can't rely on Riyad Mahrez all the time, says Wes Morgan|date=9 September 2015|accessdate=9 September 2015|publisher=Leicester Mercury|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150911235806/http://www.leicestermercury.co.uk/t-rely-Mahrez-time-ndash-Wes/story-27760222-detail/story.html|archivedate=11 September 2015|df=}}</ref>
After scoring four goals in the opening four games of the 2015–16 season, Mahrez was nominated for the [[Premier League Player of the Month]] award.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/34216391|title=Andre Ayew & Manuel Pellegrini win Premier League awards|date=11 September 2015|accessdate=13 September 2015|publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref> By 3 November 2015, he had scored seven goals in 10 Premier League games.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/34709767|title=Riyad Mahrez wary of Leicester City's rising expectations|date=3 November 2015|accessdate=3 November 2015|publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref> On 5 December, Mahrez scored a hat-trick as Leicester defeated [[Swansea City F.C.|Swansea City]] 3–0 to go top of the Premier League, putting him on ten league goals for the season and making him the first Algerian to score a [[List of Premier League hat-tricks|Premier League hat-trick]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Pritchard|first1=Dafydd|title=Swansea 0–3 Leicester|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/34951743|accessdate=20 December 2015|publisher=BBC Sport|date=5 December 2015}}</ref> Mahrez and his midfield partners [[Marc Albrighton]], [[N'Golo Kanté]] and [[Danny Drinkwater]] received plaudits for their part in Leicester's early season run of form,<ref>{{cite news|last1=Laurence|first1=Martin|title=Why Riyad Mahrez, and not Jamie Vardy, has been the player of the season so far|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/who-scored-blog/2015/dec/08/riyad-mahrez-jamie-vardy-player-season-premier-league|accessdate=17 January 2016|work=The Guardian|date=8 December 2015}}</ref> and manager [[Claudio Ranieri]] described Mahrez and forward [[Jamie Vardy]] as "priceless" ahead of the January transfer window.<ref>{{cite news|title=Jamie Vardy and Riyad Mahrez priceless – Claudio Ranieri|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/35098801|accessdate=17 January 2016|publisher=BBC Sport|date=15 December 2015}}</ref>
In January 2016 Mahrez's transfer value was said to have risen from £4.5 million to £30.1 million, ranking him among the top 50 most valuable players in Europe.<ref>{{cite web|title = Leicester City winger Riyad Mahrez ranked in top 50 most valuable players in Europe at nearly £30m|url = http://www.leicestermercury.co.uk/Leicester-City-winger-Riyad-Mahrez-ranked-50/story-28475654-detail/story.html|publisher = Leicester Mercury|date = 6 January 2016|accessdate = 7 February 2016}}{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title = Leicester City: Why we are all rooting for the Foxes|url = https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/35480812|publisher = BBC Sport|date = 3 February 2016|accessdate = 7 February 2016}}</ref> In the same year, Mahrez's popularity in his homeland led Leicester to have over almost three times as many [[Facebook]] fans in Algeria than in the UK.<ref>{{cite news|title=African players in the Premier League|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/35844104|accessdate=18 March 2016|publisher=BBC Sport|date=18 March 2016}}</ref> The barbershop in Sarcelles that he frequented from his childhood became a destination for fans from as far as Belgium, desiring the same haircut.<ref name="journey"/>
Mahrez was one of four Leicester players named in the [[PFA Team of the Year]] in April 2016,<ref name = "PFATeam">{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/36106596|title=PFA awards: Leicester and Spurs dominate Premier League team|date=21 April 2016|accessdate=21 April 2016|publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref> and later that month he won the [[PFA Players' Player of the Year]] award.<ref name = "PFAPlayer">{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/36124713|title=Riyad Mahrez: Leicester City forward named PFA Player of the Year|date=25 April 2016|accessdate=25 April 2016|publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref> He was the first African to earn the accolade.<ref>{{cite news|title=Bargain of the century Riyad Mahrez first African to win EPL player of the season|url=https://www.tvnz.co.nz/one-news/sport/football/bargain-century-riyad-mahrez-first-african-win-epl-player-season|accessdate=25 April 2016|agency=Associated Press|publisher=TVNZ|date=25 April 2016}}</ref> When Leicester finished the season as champions, Mahrez became the first Algerian to win a Premier League medal.<ref name = "PL">{{cite news|title=Leicester City: The ridiculous statistics|url=http://www.football365.com/news/leicester-city-the-ridiculous-statistics|accessdate=3 May 2016|publisher=Football 365|date=3 May 2016}}</ref>

===Manchester City=== On 10 July 2018, [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]] confirmed the signing of Mahrez on a five-year contract. 2018}}</ref> On 22 September 2018, coming on as a substitute in the 61st minute Mahrez scored a brace for Citizens against [[Cardiff City F.C.|Cardiff City]], The first goal was his first with Manchester City.<ref>{{cite news |title=Riyad Mahrez double caps five-star Manchester City’s rout of Cardiff |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/sep/22/cardiff-manchester-city-premier-league-match-report |accessdate=16 November 2018 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=22 September 2018}}</ref>
On 29 October 2018, Mahrez scored the only goal for Manchester City in a 1–0 away victory against [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]]. He dedicated the goal to [[Vichai Srivaddhanaprabha]], the former owner of his previous club Leicester City, who had recently [[2018 Leicester City F.C. helicopter crash|died in a helicopter crash]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/46026701|title=Leicester helicopter crash: Riyad Mahrez dedicates Man City goal to Foxes owner|publisher=BBC Sport|date=29 October 2018|accessdate=6 November 2018}}</ref>
==International career== [[File:Riyad Mahrez - 2014 World Cup.jpg|thumbnail|right|Mahrez playing for [[Algeria national football team|Algeria]] against [[Belgium national football team|Belgium]] at the [[2014 FIFA World Cup]].]] In November 2013, French-born Mahrez expressed his desire to represent [[Algeria national football team|Algeria]] internationally.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dzfoot.com/news-14868-verts-riyad-mahrez-je-sais-que-je-peux-jouer-en-en.php |title=Riyad Mahrez "Je sais que je peux jouer en EN" |trans-title=Riyad Mahrez "I know that I can play in the national team" |language=French |date=11 November 2013 |accessdate=11 January 2014 |publisher=DZFoot |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140112090928/http://www.dzfoot.com/news-14868-verts-riyad-mahrez-je-sais-que-je-peux-jouer-en-en.php |archivedate=12 January 2014 }}</ref> He was called up to the provisional Algeria squad for the [[2014 FIFA World Cup]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/27374742|title=World Cup 2014: Nabil Bentaleb in Algeria's 30-man squad|date=12 May 2014|accessdate=12 May 2014|publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref> On 31 May 2014, Mahrez made his international debut for the ''Desert Foxes'' as a starter in a pre-World Cup friendly match against [[Armenia national football team|Armenia]], and he was subsequently called up to the full squad for the tournament on 2 June.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lcfc.com/news/article/020614-world-cup-beckons-for-mahrez-1592375.aspx|title=World Cup Beckons For Mahrez|date=2 June 2014|accessdate=2 June 2014|publisher=Leicester City F.C.}}</ref> The Algerian media were critical of his inclusion and alleged that he had paid manager [[Vahid Halilhodžić]] for a place in the squad.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Tironi|first1=Hrvoje|title=People accused Mahrez of giving me money to go to the World Cup! – Halilhodzic|url=http://www.goal.com/en-gb/news/2565/exclusive/2016/02/13/20291192/people-accused-mahrez-of-giving-me-money-to-go-to-the-world|accessdate=4 May 2016|publisher=Goal.com|date=13 February 2016}}</ref><ref name=msn>{{cite news|last1=Ouali|first1=Amer|title=Leicester City and Riyad Mahrez gaining fans in Algeria|url=http://www.msn.com/en-us/sports/premier-league/leicester-city-and-riyad-mahrez-gaining-fans-in-algeria/ar-BBq9qOz|accessdate=4 May 2016|agency=AFP|publisher=MSN|date=29 February 2016|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160603102929/http://www.msn.com/en-us/sports/premier-league/leicester-city-and-riyad-mahrez-gaining-fans-in-algeria/ar-BBq9qOz|archivedate=3 June 2016|df=}}</ref> Mahrez played in the opening group game against [[Belgium national football team|Belgium]], then was dropped for the remainder of the tournament, in which Algeria reached the last 16.<ref name=msn/>
On 15 October 2014, Mahrez scored his first international goal, as well as setting up [[Islam Slimani]] in Algeria's 3–0, [[2015 Africa Cup of Nations qualification|Africa Cup of Nations]] qualifier against [[Malawi national football team|Malawi]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lcfc.com/news/article/151014-mahrez-stars-in-algeria-win-2017946.aspx|title=Mahrez Stars In Algeria Win|date=15 October 2014|accessdate=16 October 2014|publisher=Leicester City F.C.}}</ref> In December 2014 he was announced as a member of Algeria's squad for the [[2015 Africa Cup of Nations|final tournament in Equatorial Guinea]] for the first time.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/30477709|title=Nations Cup 2015: Newcastle's Mehdi Abeid in Algeria squad|date=15 December 2014|accessdate=18 December 2014|publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref> his first meeting was against [[South Africa national football team|South Africa]] where he participated in the 60 minutes before the change in the second throw against [[Ghana national football team|Ghana]] substitute in the last 20 minutes where the Algerian team were defeated by a single goal in their last game in the [[2015 Africa Cup of Nations Group C|group stage]] against [[Senegal national football team|Senegal]] led Mehrez the national team to the quarter-finals, scoring the first goal of a match ending 2–0.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Hughes|first1=Ian|title=Senegal 0–2 Algeria|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/30891881|accessdate=20 December 2015|publisher=BBC Sport|date=27 January 2015}}</ref> then against [[Ivory Coast national football team|Ivory Coast]] gave assists for [[El Arabi Hillel Soudani]] were not enough to exclude from the quarter-finals 3–1.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Hughes|first1=Ian|title=Ivory Coast 3–1 Algeria|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/30971819|accessdate=1 February 2015|publisher=BBC Sport|date=16 January 2017}}</ref> then in the second Round of the [[2018 FIFA World Cup qualification – CAF Second Round|2018 World Cup qualifier]] against [[Tanzania national football team|Tanzania]] helped Mehrez in the team qualified for the [[2018 FIFA World Cup qualification – CAF Third Round|group stage]] where he scored a goal and assists for [[Carl Medjani]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Hughes|first1=Ian|title=Algeria 7–0 Tanzania|url=http://www.dzfoot.com/2015/11/17/algerie-tanzanie-live-tweet-77327.php|accessdate=17 November 2015|publisher=DZfoot|date=16 January 2017}}</ref>
Mahrez was named in coach [[Georges Leekens]]' Algeria squad for the [[2017 Africa Cup of Nations]] in Gabon.<ref>{{cite news|title=Sofiane Feghouli left out of Algeria's final Africa Cup of Nations squad|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/38479829|accessdate=15 January 2017|publisher=BBC Sport|date=31 December 2016}}</ref> In their opening game, he scored both goals in a 2–2 draw with [[Zimbabwe national football team|Zimbabwe]]<ref>{{cite news|title=Algeria 2 2 Zimbabwe|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/38545952|accessdate=15 January 2017|publisher=BBC Sport|date=15 January 2017}}</ref> and was awarded Man of the Match.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/CAF_Online/status/820694598624362496|title=R. Mahrez has been selected as the Total Man of the Match! Well done!|publisher=Twitter|work=CAF|date=15 January 2017}}</ref>
In October 2017, with Algeria's chances of reaching the [[2018 FIFA World Cup]] already ended, Mahrez and his (at the time) Leicester teammate [[Islam Slimani]] were dropped from the national team, with coach [[Lucas Alcaraz]] selecting several new players.<ref>{{cite news|title=Algeria look to the future as Mahrez and Slimani are left out of World Cup qualifier|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/41455809|accessdate=6 October 2017|publisher=BBC Sport|date=1 October 2017}}</ref> On 18 November 2018, in the [[2019 Africa Cup of Nations qualification|2019 Africa Cup of Nations qualifier]] Mahrez scored a brace in a 4–1 away victory against [[Togo national football team|Togo]], His first goal with the national team since [[2017 Africa Cup of Nations]] to lead Algeria to qualify for the [[2019 Africa Cup of Nations]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Afcon 2019: Mahrez brace helps Algeria qualify for Nations Cup|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/46255664|accessdate=18 November 2018|publisher=BBC Sport|date=18 November 2018}}</ref>
==Personal life== Mahrez married his English girlfriend Rita Johal in 2015.<ref name=doyle/><ref>{{cite web|title=Mais qui est Rita, la très jolie femme de Mahrez ?|url=http://www.sports.fr/football/angleterre/articles/rita-la-tres-jolie-femme-de-riyad-mahrez-1505289/|website=Sports.fr|accessdate=6 June 2016|language=French|date=30 April 2016}}</ref> Their daughter was born later that year.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Percy|first1=John|title='Flying' Riyad Mahrez coming to terms with dramatic ascent and comparisons with Lionel Messi|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/teams/leicester-city/12048440/Flying-Riyad-Mahrez-coming-to-terms-with-dramatic-ascent-and-comparisons-with-Lionel-Messi.html|accessdate=27 April 2016|work=The Daily Telegraph|date=13 December 2015}}</ref>
Mahrez is a practising Muslim.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/sport/football/news/thriving-premier-league-shining-example-6842237|title=Thriving Premier League a shining example of multiculturalism in week of Paris terrorist attack|date=16 November 2015|accessdate=28 April 2016|author=Dave Kidd|publisher=Daily Mirror}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Duchâteau|first1=Romain|title=Riyad Mahrez, l'enfant chéri de Sarcelles|url=http://www.sofoot.com/riyad-mahrez-l-enfant-cheri-de-sarcelles-207264.html|accessdate=13 May 2016|publisher=SoFoot|date=29 August 2015|language=French}}</ref> In June 2017, he made the [[Umrah]] pilgrimage to [[Mecca]].<ref>{{cite news|title=رياض محرز يؤدي مناسك العمرة في مكة المكرمة|url=https://arabic.cnn.com/sport/2017/06/12/mahrez-omrah-mecca-algeria|accessdate=13 June 2017|publisher=CNN|date=12 June 2017|language=Arabic}}</ref>

Gonzalo Otamendi''' ({{IPA-es|nikoˈlas otaˈmendi}}; born 12 February 1988) is an Argentine professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[Defender (association football)#Centre-back|centre back]] for {{English football updater|ManchesC}} club [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]] and the [[Argentina national football team|Argentine national team]].
He played for [[Club Atlético Vélez Sarsfield|Vélez Sarsfield]] and [[FC Porto|Porto]] in his early career, winning eight major titles with the latter including three [[Primeira Liga]] championships and the [[2011 UEFA Europa League Final|2011 Europa League]]. He signed for Manchester City in 2015 from [[Valencia CF|Valencia]] (with the latter club also loaning him to [[Clube Atlético Mineiro|Atlético Mineiro]] of Brazil for four months), winning the [[Premier League]] in [[2017–18 Premier League|2017–18]] as well as three [[EFL Cup|League Cups]].
An [[Argentina national football team|Argentina international]] since 2009, Otamendi represented his country at two [[FIFA World Cup|World Cups]] and as many [[Copa América|Copas América]], in which he contributed to consecutive runner-up finishes.
==Club career== ===Vélez=== Born in [[Buenos Aires]], Otamendi made his [[Argentine Primera División|Primera División]] debut for [[Club Atlético Vélez Sarsfield]] on 10 May 2008, in a 2–1 home win against [[Rosario Central]] for the [[2007–08 Argentine Primera División#Torneo Clausura|Clausura tournament]].<ref name=Nacion>{{cite news|url=http://www.lanacion.com.ar/nota.asp?nota_id=1122686|title=Nicolás Otamendi: "El de Vélez es un grupo con hambre"|trans-title=Nicolás Otamendi: "Vélez is a hungry group"|newspaper=[[La Nación]]|language=Spanish|date=28 April 2009|accessdate=2 October 2009}}</ref> During manager [[Hugo Tocalli]]'s spell he was only fifth-choice stopper, behind [[Waldo Ponce]], [[Fernando Tobio]], [[Marco Torsiglieri]] and [[Mariano Uglessich]]. However, his role in the first team changed during [[Ricardo Gareca]]'s first season as head coach, the [[2008–09 Argentine Primera División#Torneo Clausura|2009 Clausura]]: he replaced Ponce for the third game after the [[Chile]]an was injured while playing for [[Chile national football team|his national team]],<ref name=Nacion/> and eventually won a starting position alongside [[Sebastián Domínguez]],<ref name=Nacion/> playing 17 of the 19 games in Vélez's winning campaign.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.argentinesoccer.com/player_apps.cfm?id=otmd&Championship=cl09&Team=vel|title=Closing '09 statistics|publisher=Argentine Soccer|accessdate=8 August 2010}}</ref>
Otamendi scored his first professional goal during the [[2009–10 Argentine Primera División#Torneo Apertura|2009 Apertura]], in a 3–1 victory over [[Arsenal de Sarandí]]. During that season he also made his debuts in an international club competition, [[2009 Copa Sudamericana|appearing]] in the [[Copa Sudamericana]]; in recognition of his performances throughout the year he was chosen for the ''South American Team of the Year'', in a traditional continent-wide journalists' poll conducted by the newspaper ''[[El País (Montevideo)|El País]]''.<ref name=SATY>{{cite web|url=http://www.24con.com/conurbano/nota/33849-Ver%C3%B3n-fue-elegido-como-el-mejor-jugador-de-Am%C3%A9rica/|title=Verón fue elegido como el mejor jugador de América|trans-title=Verón chosen best player in America|publisher=24CON|language=Spanish|date=31 December 2009|accessdate=31 December 2009}}</ref>
===Porto=== On 23 August 2010, Otamendi was transferred to Portuguese side [[FC Porto]] on a €4 million fee, signing a five-year contract.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.uefa.com/uefaeuropaleague/news/newsid=1517284.html|title=Porto sign Argentina defender Otamendi|publisher=UEFA|date=23 August 2010|accessdate=25 August 2010}}</ref> Vélez also retained 50% of his registration rights, with the player having a pre-set price of another €4 million to be met by Porto prior to September 2011.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fcporto.pt/IncFCP/PDF/Investor_Relations/FactosRelevantes/CompraOtamendi23082010.pdf|title=Acordo de princípio para a compra do jogador Otamendi|trans-title=Negotiations for acquisition of player Otamendi|publisher=FC Porto|language=Portuguese|date=23 August 2010|accessdate=29 August 2010|format=PDF|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110930101322/http://www.fcporto.pt/IncFCP/PDF/Investor_Relations/FactosRelevantes/CompraOtamendi23082010.pdf|archivedate=30 September 2011}}</ref> He netted in his first match, a 2–0 home victory over [[S.C. Olhanense]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.portugoal.net/index.php/more-liga-sagres-news/16655-can-anybody-stop-this-dragon|title=Can anybody stop this Dragon?|publisher=PortuGOAL|date=26 September 2010|accessdate=9 November 2012}}</ref> finishing [[2010–11 Primeira Liga|his first season]] with 15 appearances and five goals (notably both in a 2–0 away win against [[S.C. Braga]])<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.portugoal.net/index.php/more-liga-sagres-news/21069-no-let-up-from-fc-porto-and-benfica|title=No let-up from FC Porto and Benfica|publisher=PortuGOAL|date=14 February 2011|accessdate=9 November 2012}}</ref> as the [[Porto|northerners]] won the [[Primeira Liga]] championship.
On 6 September 2011, Porto exercised the rights to sign the remainder of Otamendi's playing rights.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.fifa.com/worldfootball/clubfootball/news/newsid=1505819.html|title=Porto finalise Otamendi purchase|publisher=FIFA|date=6 September 2011|accessdate=9 November 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fcporto.pt/IncFCP/PDF/Investor_Relations/FactosRelevantes/Compra50Otamendi_06092011.pdf|title=Comunicado|trans-title=Announcement|publisher=FC Porto|language=Portuguese|date=6 September 2011|accessdate=20 September 2011}}</ref> He played 30 official games during [[2011–12 Primeira Liga|the season]] to help the club to another two major titles, notably the back-to-back domestic league.
===Valencia=== [[File:Nicolás Otamendi 2015 (cropped).jpg|thumb|upright|Otamendi with Valencia in 2015]] On 5 February 2014, Otamendi was sold to [[Valencia CF]] in [[La Liga]] for €12 million, on a five-year contract starting on 1 July.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.insidespanishfootball.com/97018/valencia-confirm-signing-of-nicolas-otamendi/|title=Valencia confirm signing of Nicolás Otamendi|publisher=Inside Spanish Football|date=5 February 2014|accessdate=6 February 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140206011550/http://www.insidespanishfootball.com/97018/valencia-confirm-signing-of-nicolas-otamendi/|archivedate=6 February 2014}}</ref> He was immediately loaned to [[Clube Atlético Mineiro]] in [[Brazil]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.goal.com/es/news/21/fichajes/2014/02/07/4603034/nicolas-otamendi-jugar%C3%A1-en-atl%C3%A9tico-mineiro-cedido-por-el|title=Nicolas Otamendi jugará en Atlético Mineiro cedido por el Valencia|trans-title=Nicolas Otamendi will play in Atlético Mineiro loaned by Valencia|publisher=[[Goal (website)|Goal]]|language=Spanish|date=7 February 2014|accessdate=14 February 2014}}</ref> and played 19 times for the team from [[Belo Horizonte]], scoring once to open a 4–1 win at city rivals [[América Futebol Clube (MG)]] on 23 March in the first leg of the semi-finals of the [[Campeonato Mineiro|state championship]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.atletico.com.br/atletico-goleia-o-america-e-larga-na-frente-na-semifinal-do-mineiro/|title=Atlético goleia o América e larga na frente na semifinal do Mineiro|trans-title=Atlético thrash América and lead the ''Mineiro'' semi-final|publisher=Atlético Mineiro|language=Portuguese|date=23 March 2014|accessdate=13 June 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://en.valenciacf.com/ver/36643/nicolas-otamendi.html?temporada=2014|title=Nicolás Otamendi|publisher=Valencia CF|accessdate=20 June 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150321053608/http://en.valenciacf.com/ver/36643/nicolas-otamendi.html?temporada=2014|archivedate=21 March 2015}}</ref>
Otamendi made his debut in the [[Spanish football league system|Spanish top level]] on 23 August 2014, starting in a 1–1 away draw against [[Sevilla FC]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.marca.com/eventos/marcador/futbol/2014_15/primera/jornada_1/sev_val/|title=Punto de fe del Valencia|trans-title=Valencia point of faith|newspaper=[[Marca (newspaper)|Marca]]|last=Campos|first=Tomás|language=Spanish|date=23 August 2014|accessdate=3 September 2014}}</ref> He scored his first goal for his new club on 4 October, helping to a 3–1 home success over [[Atlético Madrid]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.superdeporte.es/valencia/2014/10/02/valencia-atletico-madrid-partido-directo-tv-online/236350.html|title=El Valencia derroca al campeón de Liga|trans-title=Valencia knock League champions out|newspaper=[[Super Deporte]]|last=Bengoa|first=Javier|language=Spanish|date=4 October 2014|accessdate=4 October 2014}}</ref>
On 4 January 2015, Otamendi headed Valencia's winner in a 2–1 home win over [[Real Madrid C.F.|Real Madrid]], ending their opponents' club record 22-match winning streak as a result.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/30673410|title=Valencia 2–1 Real Madrid|publisher=[[BBC Sport]]|last=Oliver|first=Pete|date=4 January 2015|accessdate=4 January 2015}}</ref> After helping ''Los Che'' [[2015–16 UEFA Champions League|qualify]] for the [[UEFA Champions League]] for the first time in four years, becoming the first club stopper to score six goals in the league in the process,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://valencia.eldesmarque.com/valencia-cf/noticias/4369-historico-otakaiser-primer-central-che-que-marca-seis-goles-en-liga|title=Histórico 'Otakaiser': primer central che que marca seis goles en Liga|trans-title=Historical 'Otakaiser': first ''che'' stopper who scores six goals in League|publisher=El Desmarque|last=Gimeno|first=Manu|language=Spanish|date=23 May 2015|accessdate=8 September 2015}}</ref> he was the only player from his team to be named in the La Liga Team of the Year.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-3126163/Lionel-Messi-Cristiano-Ronaldo-lead-La-Liga-team-year-Gareth-Bale-misses-out.html|title=Cristiano Ronaldo and Lionel Messi lead La Liga team of the year... but there's no place for Gareth Bale after disappointing season|newspaper=[[Daily Mail]]|last=Skinner|first=Adam|date=17 June 2015|accessdate=24 June 2015}}</ref>
===Manchester City=== Late into the 2015 pre-season, Otamendi refused to train or play with Valencia to avoid thwarting his chances of signing with another club.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.mundodeportivo.com/futbol/valencia/20150814/201242126032/otamendi-se-niega-a-jugar-con-el-valencia.html|title=Otamendi se niega a jugar con el Valencia|trans-title=Otamendi refuses to play with Valencia|newspaper=[[Mundo Deportivo]]|language=Spanish|date=15 August 2015|accessdate=8 September 2015}}</ref> On 20 August, he joined [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]] on a five-year deal for an initial fee of £28.5 million.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mcfc.com/News/Team-news/2015/August/Manchester-City-sign-Nicolas-Otamendi-from-Valencia/1439913882|title=Nicolas Otamendi joins City|publisher=Manchester City F.C|date=20 August 2015|accessdate=20 August 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/34002463|title=Nicolas Otamendi: Manchester City sign £32m Argentina defender|publisher=BBC Sport|date=20 August 2015|accessdate=20 August 2015}}</ref> He made his debut on 15 September, coming on as a 75th-minute [[Substitute (association football)|substitute]] for [[Vincent Kompany]] in a 1–2 home loss against [[Juventus F.C.]] for the [[2015–16 UEFA Champions League|Champions League]] [[2015–16 UEFA Champions League group stage|group phase]];<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.uefa.com/uefachampionsleague/season=2016/matches/round=2000634/match=2015671/postmatch/report/index.html|title=Morata earns Juventus victory at Manchester City|publisher=UEFA.com|date=15 September 2015|accessdate=15 September 2015}}</ref> his [[Premier League]] debut came four days later, in a 1–2 defeat to [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]] at the [[City of Manchester Stadium]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/34191909|title=Manchester City 1–2 West Ham United|publisher=BBC Sport|last=Jurejko|first=Jonathan|date=19 September 2015|accessdate=1 November 2015}}</ref>
On 31 October 2015, Otamendi scored his first goal for the club in a 2–1 home win over [[Norwich City F.C.|Norwich City]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/34623887|title=Manchester City 2–1 Norwich City|publisher=BBC Sport|last=Osborne|first=Chris|date=31 October 2015|accessdate=1 November 2015}}</ref> He played the full 120 minutes as they [[2015–16 Football League Cup|won]] the [[Football League Cup]] on 28 February 2016, defeating [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] on a [[Penalty shoot-out (association football)|penalty shootout]] in [[2016 Football League Cup Final|the final]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/35624164|title=Liverpool 1–1 Manchester City|publisher=BBC Sport|last=McNulty|first=Phil|date=28 February 2016|accessdate=13 June 2016}}</ref>
==International career== [[File:Nicolás Otamendi.jpg|thumbnail|Otamendi playing for [[Argentina national football team|Argentina]] in 2009]] In April 2009, Otamendi was called up by [[Argentina national football team|Argentine national team]] coach [[Diego Maradona]] for a [[Exhibition game|friendly]] with [[Panama national football team|Panama]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.ole.clarin.com/notas/2009/04/17/seleccion/01899938.html|title=Bocación local|trans-title=Local bocation|newspaper=[[Olé (sports newspaper)|Olé]]|last=Sottile|first=Marcelo|language=Spanish|date=17 April 2009|accessdate=2 October 2009}}</ref> At the time of his selection he had only played 11 professional games,<ref name=Nacion/> and eventually started the match on 20 May, in a 3–1 win.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.lanacion.com.ar/1130238-con-destellos-la-argentina-vencio-a-panama-3-a-1|title=Con destellos, la Argentina venció a Panamá 3 a 1|trans-title=With flashes, Argentina beat Panama 3 to 1|newspaper=La Nación|language=Spanish|date=20 May 2009|accessdate=24 November 2018}}</ref>
During the [[2010 FIFA World Cup]] [[2010 FIFA World Cup qualification (CONMEBOL)|qualifying campaign]], Otamendi played as a centre back alongside [[Martín Demichelis]] against [[Ecuador national football team|Ecuador]] (0–2 away loss), partnered former Vélez teammate Domínguez against [[Brazil national football team|Brazil]] in a 1–3 home defeat and appeared as a right back in a 1–0 win in [[Uruguay national football team|Uruguay]] which sealed the country's qualification to South Africa.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lacapitalmdp.com/noticias/Deportes/2009/10/11/123504.htm|title=Maradona probó con Otamendi como lateral|trans-title=Maradona tested Otamendi as fullback|publisher=La Capital MdP|language=Spanish|date=11 October 2009|accessdate=8 September 2015}}</ref> On 19 May 2010 he was confirmed as part of the 23-men squad for the final stages,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.ole.com.ar/mundial/argentina/Maradona_0_264573643.html|title=¡Acá están, estos son!|trans-title=These are the guys!|newspaper=Olé|language=Spanish|date=19 May 2010|accessdate=19 May 2010}}</ref> featuring in the starting eleven for the [[2010 FIFA World Cup Group B#Greece vs Argentina|final group stage game]] against [[Greece national football team|Greece]]; on the press conference after the match, Maradona said that, in his opinion, he was the best player on the field.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.ole.com.ar/mundial/argentina/Liniers-queda-Sudafrica_0_285571449.html|title=Liniers queda en Sudáfrica|trans-title=Liniers stays in South Africa|newspaper=Olé|language=Spanish|date=23 June 2010|accessdate=23 June 2010}}</ref>
Otamendi also played the 90 minutes of the [[2010 FIFA World Cup knockout stage#Argentina vs Mexico|round-of-16 game]] against [[Mexico national football team|Mexico]], which Argentina won by 3–1. His final appearance in the tournament was the 0–4 [[2010 FIFA World Cup knockout stage#Argentina vs Germany|quarter-final]] loss to [[Germany national football team|Germany]]: this time his performance received criticism by the football press, as did his manager's decision to improvise him on the right-back position;<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.goal.com/en-gb/news/2890/world-cup-2010/2010/07/04/2009766/world-cup-2010-comment-javier-zanetti-or-nicolas-otamendi|title=World Cup 2010 Comment: Javier Zanetti or Nicolas Otamendi? The decision to snub Inter's captain cost Maradona & Argentina|publisher=Goal|last=Edwards|first=Daniel|date=4 July 2010|accessdate=16 July 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/worldcup2010/article-1291953/WORLD-CUP-2010-Diego-Maradona-finally-exposed-Argentinas-weakest-link--right-back.html|title=Diego Maradona finally exposed as Argentina's weakest link... along with their right full back|newspaper=[[Daily Mail]]|last=Ladyman|first=Ian|date=5 July 2010|accessdate=16 July 2010}}</ref> however, the player subsequently stated his desire to always play for his national team, even if not in his natural position.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.ole.com.ar/seleccion/Quiero-jugar-siempre-posicion_0_299370177.html|title=Quiero jugar siempre aunque no sea en mi puesto|trans-title=I want to play always even if it's out of position|newspaper=Olé|language=Spanish|date=16 July 2010|accessdate=16 July 2010}}</ref>
Otamendi scored his first goal for Argentina on 2 September 2011, in a 1–0 friendly win over [[Venezuela national football team|Venezuela]] in [[Kolkata]], after heading a [[Corner kick|corner]] taken by [[Lionel Messi]].<ref name="goal1">{{cite news|url=http://www.elcomercio.com/deportes/futbol/Argentina-Sabella-comienza-Venezuela-Calcuta_0_547145327.html|title=La Argentina de Sabella comienza con victoria ante Venezuela en Calcuta|trans-title=Sabella's Argentina start with win against Venezuela in Kolkata|newspaper=El Comercio|language=Spanish|date=2 September 2011|accessdate=1 February 2014}}</ref> After being cut from the squad that later appeared at the [[2014 FIFA World Cup|2014 World Cup]],<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.fifa.com/world-match-centre/news/newsid/248/732/7/|title=Otamendi making the most of every opportunity|publisher=FIFA|date=3 December 2014|accessdate=14 June 2015}}</ref> he was selected by coach [[Gerardo Martino]] for the [[2015 Copa América]],<ref>{{cite news|url=http://canchallena.lanacion.com.ar/1796405-gerardo-martino-confirmo-la-lista-de-23-convocados-y-mantuvo-a-casco-para-la-copa-america|title=Gerardo Martino confirmó la lista de 23 convocados y mantuvo a Casco para la Copa América|trans-title=Gerardo Martino confirmed list of 23 selected and kept Casco for the Copa América|newspaper=La Nación|language=Spanish|date=27 May 2015|accessdate=27 May 2015}}</ref> playing the entirety of all but one match as they lost to hosts [[Chile national football team|Chile]] on a penalty shootout in [[2015 Copa América Final|the final]]; he was named in the Team of the Tournament.<ref name=TOTT>{{cite web|url=http://www.ca2015.com/en/gallery/copa-america-2015---team-of-the-tournament/1nqqmzngdosa911z9l2g8k8317/slide/13|title=Copa América 2015 – Team of the tournament|publisher=[[CONMEBOL]]|date=5 July 2015|accessdate=5 July 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150707200522/http://www.ca2015.com/en/gallery/copa-america-2015---team-of-the-tournament/1nqqmzngdosa911z9l2g8k8317/slide/13|archivedate= 7 July 2015|df=}}</ref>
Otamendi started all the games in the [[Copa América Centenario]] in the United States, in which Argentina again both faced Chile in the tournament final and lost in a penalty shootout, [[Copa América Centenario Final|2–4]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/jun/26/chile-win-copa-america-argentina-match-report-penalty-shoot-out|title=Chile win Copa América once again as Argentina title drought continues|newspaper=[[The Guardian]]|last=Timms|first=Aaron|date=27 June 2016|accessdate=27 June 2016}}</ref> In the second group match against [[Panama national football team|Panama]], on 10 June 2016, he scored the opening goal in a 5–0 win.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/jun/10/lionel-messi-hat-trick-argentina-panama-copa-america|title=Lionel Messi scores brilliant hat-trick as Argentina surge into quarter-finals|newspaper=The Guardian|date=11 June 2016|accessdate=11 June 2016}}</ref>
Otamendi was included in the squad for the [[2018 FIFA World Cup|2018 World Cup]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/44203700|title=World Cup 2018: Messi and Aguero in Argentina squad but Icardi out|publisher=BBC Sport|date=21 May 2018|accessdate=23 May 2018}}</ref>
